publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scaenae prima
div.stage: Enter 2. Uſhers, and Groomes with perfumes.

sp.speaker: 1. Uſher.
sp.l: _ROund, round, perfume it round, quick, loook ye
Diligently the ſtate be right, are theſe the richeſt
Cuſhions? Fie, fie, who waits i'th' wardrobe?

sp.speaker: 2 Uſh.
sp.l: But pray tell me, do you thinke for certaine
Theſe Ambaſſadours ſhall have this morning audience?

sp.speaker: 1. Uſh.
sp.l: They ſhall have it: Lord that you live at Court
And underſtand not? I tell you they muſt have it.

sp.speaker: 2 Uſh.
sp.l: Upon what neceſſity?

sp.speaker: 1 Uſh.
sp.l: Still you are of the tricke of Court, ſell your place
And ſow your grounds, you are not for this tillage.
Madams, the beſt way is the upper lodgings,
There you may ſee at eaſe.

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.l: We thanke you ſir. Ex. Ladies, Gent.

sp.speaker: 1 Uſh.
sp.l: Would you have al theſe ſlighted? who ſhould report then
The Embaſſadors were hanſome men? his beard
A neat one? the fire of his eyes quicker then lightning,
And when it breaks, as blaſting? his legs, though litle ones,
Yet movers of a maſſe of underſtanding?
Who ſhall commend their cloaths: who ſhall take notice
Of the moſt wiſe behaviour of their feathers?
Ye live a raw man here.

sp.speaker: 2 Uſh.
sp.l: I thinke I doe ſo.

sp.speaker: 1 Uſh.
sp.l: Why, whether would you all preſſe?

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: Good Maſter Uſher.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: My wife, and ſome few of my honeſt neighbours, here.

sp.speaker: 1 Uſh.
sp.l: Prethee begon thou and thy honeſt neighbours,
Thou lookſt like an aſſe, why, whether would you fiſh face

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: If I might have
But the honour to ſee you at my poore houſe ſir,
A Capon bridled, and ſadled I'le aſſure your worſhip,
A ſhoulder of mutton, and a pottle of wine ſir;
I know your brother, he was as like ye,
And ſhot the beſt at buts—

sp.speaker: 1 Uſh.
sp.l: A—upon thee.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: Some muſick I'le aſſure you too,
My toy ſir, can play o'th' virginals.

sp.speaker: 1 Uſh.
sp.l: Prethee good toy,
Take away thy ſhoulder of mutton, it is flie blowne,
And ſhoulder take thy flap along, here's no place for ye;
Nay then you had beſt be knock'd. Ez. Cit.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I wou'd faine ſee him
The glory of this place, makes me remember,
But dye thoſe thoughts, dye all but my deſires,
Even thoſe to death are ſicke too; he's not here,
Nor how my eyes may guide me—

sp.speaker: 1 Uſh.
sp.l: What's your buſineſſe?
Who keeps the outward doore there? here's fine ſhufling,
You waſtcoater you muſt go backe.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: There is not,
There cannot be, ſixe dayes and never ſee me?
There muſt not be deſire; ſit do you thinke
That if you had a Miſtris—

sp.speaker: 1 Uſh.
sp.l: Death, ſhe is mad.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And were your ſelfe an honeſt man? it cannot—

sp.speaker: 1 Uſh.
sp.l: What a devill haſt thou to do with me or my honeſty?
Will you be jogging, good nimble tongue,
My fellow doore keeper.

sp.speaker: 2 Uſh.
sp.l: Prethee let her alone.

sp.speaker: 1 Uſh.
sp.l: The King is comming,
And ſhall we have an agent from the ſuburbs
Come to crave audience too?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Before I thought ye
To have a little breeding, ſome tang of Gentry;
But now I take ye plainly,
Without the helpe of any perſpective,
For that ye cannot alter.

sp.speaker: 1 Uſh
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: An aſſe ſir, you bray as like one,
And by my troth, me thinkes as ye ſtand now,
Conſidering who to kick next, you appeare to me
Juſt with that kind of gravity, and wiſdome;
Your place may beare the name of Gentleman,
But if ever any of that butter ſtick to your bread—

sp.speaker: 2 Uſh.
sp.l: You muſt be modeſter.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Let him uſe me nobler,
And weare good cloaths to do good offices;
They hang upon a fellow of his vertue,
As though they hung on Gibbets.

sp.speaker: 2. Uſh.
sp.l: A perilous wench.

sp.speaker: 1 Uſh.
sp.l: Thruſt her into a corner, I'le no more on her.

sp.speaker: 2 Uſh.
sp.l: You have enough, goe pretty maid, ſtand cloſe,
And uſe that little tongue, with a little more temper.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I thanke ye ſir.

sp.speaker: 2 Uſh.
sp.l: When the ſhews are paſt,
I'le have ye into the cellar, there wee'l dine
A very pretty wench, a witty rogue,
And there wee'l be as merry, can ye be merry?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: O very merry.

sp.speaker: 2 Uſh.
sp.l: Only our ſelves; this churliſh fellow ſhall not know.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: By no meanes.

sp.speaker: 2 Uſh.
sp.l: And can you love a little?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Love exceedingly:
I have cauſe to love you deare ſir.

sp.speaker: 2 Uſh.
sp.l: Then I'le carry ye,
And ſhew you all the pictures, and the hangings,
The lodgings, gardens, and the walkes: and then (ſweet)
You ſhall tell me where you lye.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Yes marry will I.

sp.speaker: 2. Uſh.
sp.l: And't ſhall go hard but I'le ſend ye a veniſon pa|ſtie,
And bring a bottle of wine along.

sp.speaker: 1. Uſh.
sp.l: Make roome there.

sp.speaker: 2. Uſh.
sp.l: Room there afore, ſtand cloſe, the train is coming

div.stage: Enter King, Antigonous, Tymon, Charinthus, Menippus.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Have I yet left a beauty to Catch fooles?
Yet, yet, I ſee him not, O what a miſerie
Is love, expected long, deluded longer!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Conduct in the Embaſſadors.

sp.speaker: 1. Uſh.
sp.l: Make roome there.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: They ſhall not wait long anſwer — Flouriſh Ent. 3 Embaſſadors.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Yet he comes not.
Why are eyes ſet on theſe, and multitudes
Follow to make theſe wonders? O good gods!
What would theſe looke like if my love were here?
But I am fond, forgetfull.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now your grievance,
Speake ſhort, and have as ſhort diſpatch.

sp.speaker: 1. Em.
sp.l: Then thus ſir:
In all our Royall Maſters names, We tell you
Ye have done injuſtice, broke the bonds of concord,
And from their equall ſhares, from Alexander
Parted, and ſo poſſeſs'd, not like a brother,
But as an open Enemie, Ye have hedged in
Whole Provinces, man'd and maintain'd theſe injuries;
And daily with your ſword (though they ſtill honor ye)
Make bloudy roades, take Townes, and ruine Caſtles,
And ſtill their ſufferance feeles the waight.

sp.speaker: 2. Em.
sp.l: Think of that love great ſir, that honor'd friend|ſhip
Your ſelfe hold with our Maſters, thinke of that ſtrength
When you were all one body, all one minde;
When all your ſwords ſtrook one way, when your angers,
Like ſo many brother billowes roſe together,
And curling up your foaming creſts, defied
Even mighty Kings, and in their fals, entomb'd 'em;
O thinke of theſe; and you that have been Conquerours,
That ever led your fortunes open ey'd,
Chain'd faſt by confidence; you that fame courted,
Now ye want enemies and men to match ye;
Let not your owne ſwords ſeeke your ends to ſhame ye.

div.stage: Enter Demetrius with a Javelin, and Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 3 Emb.
sp.l: Chooſe which you will, or peace or war,
We come prepar'd for either.

sp.speaker: 1 Uſh.
sp.l: Roome for the Prince there.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: was it the Prince they ſaid? how my heart trem|bl'd!
'Tis he indeed; what a ſweet noble fierceneſſe
Dwels in his eyes? young Meleager like,
When he returnd from ſlaughter of the Boare,
Crown'd with the loves and honours of the people,
With all the gallant youth of Greece, he lookes now,
Who could deny him love?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Haile Royall Father.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ye are welcome from your ſport ſir, do you ſee this, gent.
You that bring thunders in your mouthes, and earthquakes
To ſhake and totter my deſignes? can you imagine
(You men of poore and common apprehenſions)
Whilſt I admit this man, my ſon, this nature
That in one looke carries more fire, and fierceneſſe,
Then all your maſters in their lives: dare I admit him,
Admit him thus, even to my ſide, My boſome,
When he is fit to rule, when all men cry him,
And all hopes hang about his head; thus place him,
His weapon hatcht in bloud, all theſe attending
When he ſhall make their fortunes, all as ſudden
In any expedition he ſhall point 'em,
As arrowes from a Tartars bow, and ſpeeding,
Dare I do this, and feare an enemy?
Feare your great Maſter? yours? or yours?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: O Hercules,
Who ſaies you do ſir? Is there any thing
In theſe mens faces, or their Maſters actions,
Able to worke ſuch wonders?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Now 'a ſpeakes:
O I could dwell upon that tongue for ever.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You call 'em Kings, they never wore thoſe roialties
Nor in the progreſſe of their lives ariv'd yet
At any thought of King: emperiall dignities,
And powerfull god-like actions, fit for Princes
They can no more put on, and make 'em ſit right,
Then I can with this mortall hand hold heaven:
Poore petty men, nor have I yet forgot
The chiefeſt honours time, and merit gave 'em:
Lyſimachus your Maſter, at his beſt,
His higheſt, and his hopefull'ſt dignities
Was but grand-maſter of the Elephants;
Seleucus of the Treaſure; and for Ptolomy,
A thing not thought on then, ſcarce heard of yet,
Some maſter of amunition: and muſt theſe men—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What a brave confidence flowes from his ſpirit?
O ſweet young man!

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Muſt theſe hold pace with us,
And on the ſame field hang their memories?
Muſt theſe examine what the wils of Kings are?
Preſcribe to their deſignes, and chaine their actions
To their reſtraints? be freinds, and foes when they pleaſe?
Send out their thunders, and their menaces,
As if the fate of mortall thinge were theirs?
Go home good men, and tell your maſters from us,
We do 'em too much honour to force from 'em
Their barren countries, ruine their vaſt Cities,
And tell 'em out of love, we meane to leave 'em
(Since they will needs be Kings) no more to tread on,
Then they have able wits, and powers to manage,
And ſo we ſhall befriend 'em: ha? what does ſhe there?

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: This is your anſwer King.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis like to prove ſo.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Fie ſweet, what make you here?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Pray ye do not chide me.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You do your ſelfe much wrong, and me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Pray you pardon me,
I feele my fault, which only was committed
Through my deare love to you: I have not ſeen ye,
And how can I live then? I have not ſpoke to ye—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I know this weeke ye have not; I will redeem all.
You are ſo tender now: thinke where you are, ſweet.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What other light have I left?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Prethee Celia,
Indeed, I'le ſee ye preſently.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I have done ſir:
You will not miſſe?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: By this, and this, I will not.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis in your will: and I muſt be obedient.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: No more of theſe aſſemblies.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I am commanded.

sp.speaker: 1 Uſh.
sp.l: Roome for the Lady there: Madam, my ſervice—

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: My Coach and't pleaſe you Lady.

sp.speaker: 2 Uſh.
sp.l: Roome before there.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: The honour Madam, but to waite upon you—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: My ſervants, and my ſtate:
Lord, how they flocke now?
Before I was affraid they would have beat me;
How theſe flies play i'th Sunſhine? pray ye no ſervices,
Or if ye needs muſt play the hobby horſes,
Seek out ſome beautie that affects 'em: farewell,
Nay pray ye ſpare: Gentlemen I am old enough
To go alone at theſe yeares, without crutches. Exit.

sp.speaker: 2. Uſh.
sp.l: Wel, I could curſe now: but that will not help me,
I made as ſure account of this wench now, immediately,
Do but conſider how the devill has croſt me,
Meate for my Maſter ſhe cries, well —

sp.speaker: 3 Em.
sp.l: Once more ſir,
We aske your reſolutions: peace or war yet?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: War, war, my noble father.

sp.speaker: 1 Em.
sp.l: Thus I fling it:
And faire ey'd peace, farewell.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You have your anſwer;
Conduct out the Embaſſadours, and give 'em convoies.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Tell your high hearted Maſters, they ſhall not ſeek us,
Nor coole i'th' field in expectation of us,
Wee'l eaſe your men thoſe marches: In their ſtrengths,
And full abilities of mind and courage,
Wee'l ffnd 'em out, and at their beſt trim buckle with 'em

sp.speaker: 3 Em.
sp.l: You will find ſo hot a Souldiers welcome ſir,
Your favor ſhall not freeze,

sp.speaker: 2 Em.
sp.l: A forward Gentleman,
Pitty the wars ſhould bruiſe ſuch hopes—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Conduct 'em — Ex. Em.
Now, For this preparation: where's Leontius?
Call him in preſently: for I meane in perſon Gentlemen
My ſelfe, with my old fortune—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Royall ſir:
Thus low I beg this honour: fame already
Hath every where rais'd trophies to your glory,
And conqueſt now grown old, and weake with following
The weary marches, and the bloudy ſhockes
You daily ſet her in: 'tis now ſcarce honour
Fo you that never knew to fight, but conquer,
To ſparkle ſuch poore people: the roiall Eagle
When ſhe hath tri'd her young ones gainſt the Sun,
And found 'em right; next teacheth 'em to prey,
How to command on wing, and check below her
Even birds of noble plume; I am your owne ſir,
You have found my ſpirit, trie it now, and teach it,
To ſtoop whole kingdomes: leave a little for me;
Let not your glory be ſo greedy ſir,
To eate up all my hopes; you gave me life,
If to that life you adde not what's more laſting,
A noble name, for man you have made a ſhadow:
Bleſſe me this day: bid me go on, and lead,
Bid me go on, no leſſe fear'd, then Antigonus,
And to my maiden ſword, tye faſt your fortune;
I know 'twill fight it ſelfe then: deare ſir honour me:
Never faire virgin long'd ſo.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Riſe, and command then,
And be as fortunate as I expect ye:
I love that noble will; your young companions
Bred up and foſter'd with ye, I hope Demetrius. Enter Leon.
You will make ſouldiers too: they muſt not leave ye.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Never till life leave us ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O Leontius,
Here's worke for you in hand.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I am ev'n right glad ſir.
For by my troath, I am now grown old with idleneſſe;
I heare we ſhall abroad ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, and preſently,
But who thinkes you commands now?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Who commands ſir?
Methinkes mine eye ſhould guide me: can there be
(If you your ſelfe will ſpare him ſo much honour)
Any found out to lead before your armies,
So full of faith, and fire as brave Demetrius?
King Philips Son, at his yeares was an old Souldier,
'Tis time his fortune be a wing, high time ſir,
So many idle houres, as here he loyters,
So many ever-living names he loſes,
I hope 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis he indeed, and nobly
He ſhall ſet forward: draw you all thoſe Garriſons
Upon the frontiers as you paſſe: to thoſe
Joyne theſe in pay at home, our ancient ſouldiers,
And as you go preſſe all the Provinces.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: We ſhall not need;
Beleeve, this hopefull Gentleman
Can want no ſwords, nor honeſt hearts to follow him,
We ſhall be full, no feare ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You Leontius,
Becauſe you are an old, and faithfull ſervant,
And know the wars, with all his vantages,
Be neare to his inſtructions, leaſt his youth
Loſe valours beſt companion, ſtaid diſcretion,
Shew where to lead, to lodge, to charge with ſafetie;
In execution not to breake, nor ſcatter,
But with a provident anger, follow nobly:
Not covetous of bloud, and death, but honour,
Be ever neare his watches; cheere his labours,
And where his hope ſtands faire, provoke his valour;
Love him, and thinke it no diſhonour (my Demetrius)
To weare this Jewell neare thee; he is a tri'd one,
And one that even in ſpight of time, that ſunke him,
And froſted up his ſtrength, will yet ſtand by thee.
And with the proudeſt of thine enemies
Exchange for bloud, and bravely: take his counſell.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Your grace hath made me young again, and wanton.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She muſt be known and ſuddenly; when you have done
Come in and take your leave ſir, and ſome few
Prayers along.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do ye know her?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Char. No, beleeve ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Did you obſerve her Tymon?

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: I look'd on her,
But what ſhe is —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I muſt have that found.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Well ſir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I know my duty, Exit. Ant.
You ſhall be halfe my father.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: All your Servant:
Come Gentlemen, you are reſolv'd I am ſure
To ſee theſe wars.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: We dare not leave his fortunes,
Though moſt aſſured death hung round about us.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: That bargaines yet to make;
Be not too haſty, when ye face the Enemie,
Nor too ambitious to get honour inſtantly,
But charge within your bounds, and keepe cloſe bodies,
And you ſhall ſee what ſport wee'l make theſe mad-caps;
You ſhall have game enough, I warrant ye,
Every mans Cock ſhall fight.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I muſt go ſee ſir:
Brave ſir, as ſoone as I have taken leave,
I'le meet you in the Parck;
Draw the men thether,
Waite you upon Leontius.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Wee'l attend ſir.

sp.speaker: Lie.
sp.l: But I beſeech your Grace, with ſpeed; the ſooner
We are i'th' field—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You could not pleaſe me better. Exit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You never ſaw the wars yet?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Not yet Collonell.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Theſe fooliſh Miſtriſſes do ſo hang about ye,
So whimper, and ſo hug, I know it Gentlemen,
And ſo intice ye, now ye are i'th' bud;
And that ſweet tilting war, with eies and kiſſes,
Th' allarums of ſoft vowes, and ſighes, and fiddle faddles,
Spoiles all our trade: You muſt forget theſe knick knacks,
A woman at ſome time of yeare, I grant ye
She is neceſſarie; but make no buſines of her;
How now Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Oh ſir, as ill as eves;
We ſhall have wars they ſay; they are muſtring yonder:
Would we were at it once: fie, how it plagues me.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Here's one has ſerved now under Captaine Cupid,
And crackt a Pike in's youth: you ſee whats come on't.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: No, my diſeaſe will never prove ſo honourable.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Why ſure, thou haſt the beſt pox.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: If I have'em,
I am ſure I got 'em in the beſt companie;
They are pox of thirty Coates.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Thou haſt mewed 'em finely:
Here's a ſtrange fellow now, and a brave fellow,
If we may ſay ſo of a pockie fellow,
(Which I beleeve we may) this poore Lieutenant;
Whether he have the ſcratches, or the ſcabs,
Or what a devill it be, I'le ſay this for him,
There ſights no braver ſouldier under Sun, gentlemen;
Show him an Enemie, his paine's forgot ſtraight;
And where other men, by beds and bathes have eaſe,
And eaſie rules of phiſick, ſet him in a danger,
A danger, thats a fearfull one indeed,
Ye rock him, and he will ſo play about ye,
Let it be ten to one, he ne're comes off againe;
Ye have his heart: and then he works it bravely,
And throughly bravely: not a pang remembred:
I have ſeen him do ſuch things, beliefe would ſhrinke at.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: 'Tis ſtrange he ſhould do all this, and diſeas'd ſo.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I am ſure 'tis true: Lieutenant, canſt thou drink wel?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Would I were drunk, dog-drunk, I might not feele this.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I would take Phiſicke.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: But I would know my diſeaſe firſt.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Why? it may be the Collique: canſt thou, blow backward?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: There's never a bag-pipe in the kingdom better.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Is't not a plureſie?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: 'Tis any thing
That has the devill, and death in't: will ye march Gentlemen?
The Prince has taken leave.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How know ye that?

sp.speaker: Lie.
sp.l: I ſaw him leave the Court, diſpatch his followers,
And met him after in a bye ſtreet: I thinke
He has ſome wench, or ſuch a toy, to lick over
Before he goe: would I had ſuch another
To draw this fooliſh paine downe.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Let's away Gentlemen,
For ſure the Prince will ſtay on us.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Wee'l attend ſir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Muſt ye needs go?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Or ſtay with all diſhonour.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Are there not men enough to fight?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Fie Celia,
This ill becomes the noble love you beare me;
Would you have your love a coward?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No; beleeve ſir,
I would have him fight, but not ſo far off from me.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Wouldſt have it thus? or thus?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: If that be fighting—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Ye wanton foole: when I come home againe
I'le fight with thee, at thine weapon Celia,
And conquer thee too.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: That you have done already,
You need no other Armes to me, but theſe ſir;
But will you fight your ſelfe ſir?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thus deep in bloud wench,
And through the thickeſt rankes of Pikes.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Spur bravely,
Your firie Courſer, beat the troopes before ye,
And crambe the mouth of death with executions.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I would do more then theſe: But prethee tell me,
Tell me my faire, where got'ſt thou this male ſpirit?
I wonder at thy mind.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Were I man then,
You would wonder more.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Sure thou wouldſt prove a Souldier,
And ſome great Leader.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sure I ſhould do ſomewhat;
And the firſt thing I did, I ſhould grow envious,
Extreamely envious of your youth, and honour.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And fight againſt me?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Ten to one, I ſhould do it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thou wouldſt not hurt me?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: In this mind I am in,
I thinke I ſhould be hardly brought to ſtrike ye,
Unleſſe 'twere thus; but in my mans mind—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I ſhould be friends with ye too,
Now I thinke better.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Ye are a tall Souldier:
Here, take theſe, and theſe;
This gold to furniſh ye, and keepe this bracelet;
Why do you weep now?
You a maſculine ſpirit?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No, I confeſſe I am a foole, a woman:
And ever when I part with you —

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You ſhall not,
Theſe teares are like prodigious ſignes, my ſweet one,
I ſhall come backe, loden with fame, to honour thee.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I hope you ſhall:
But then my deare Demetrius,
When you ſtand Conquerour, and at your mercy
All people bow, and all things waite your ſentence;
Say then your eye (ſurveying all your conqueſt)
Finds out a beautie, even in ſorrow excellent,
A conſtant face, that in the midſt of ruine
With a forc'd ſmile, both ſcornes at fate, and fortune:
Say you find ſuch a one, ſo nobly fortified,
And in her figure, all the ſweets of nature?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Prethee,
No more of this, I cannot find her.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: That ſhews as far beyond my wither'd beauty;
And will run mad, to love ye too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Do you feare me,
And do you thinke, beſides this face, this beauty,
This heart, where all my hopes are lock'd—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I dare not:
No ſure, I think ye honeſt; wondrous honeſt.
Pray doe not frowne, Ile ſwear ye are.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Ye may chooſe.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But how long will ye be away?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I know you are angry now: pray look upon me:
Ile aske no more ſuch queſtions.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: The Drums beat,
I can no longer ſtay.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: They doe but call yet:
How faine you would leave my company.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I wou'd not,
Unleſſe a greater power then love commanded,
Commands my life, mine honour.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But a little.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Prethee farewell, and be not doubtfull of me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I would not have ye hurt: and ye are ſo ventrous—
But good ſweet Prince preſerve your ſelfe, fight nobly,
But do not thruſt this body; 'tis not yours now,
'Tis mine, 'tis onely mine: doe not ſeek wounds, Sir,
For every drop of bloud you bleed —

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I will Celia,
I will be carefull.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: My heart, that loves ye deerely.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Prethee no more, we muſt part: Drums a March.
Harke, they march now.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Pox on theſe bawling Drums: I am ſure you'll kiſſe me,
But one kiſſe? what a parting's this?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Here take me,
And doe what thou wilt with me, ſmother me;
But ſtill remember, if your fooling with me,
Make me forget the truſt—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I have done: farewell ſir,
Never look back, you ſhall not ſtay, not a minute.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I muſt have one farewell more.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No, the Drums beat;
I dare not ſlack your honour; not a hand more,
Onely this look; the gods preſerve, and ſave ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What have ye found her out?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: We have hearkned after her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What's that to my deſire?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Your grace muſt give us time,
And a little meanes.

sp.speaker: Ty.
sp.l: She is ſure a ſtranger,
If ſhe were bred or knowne here—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Your dull endeavours Enter Menippus.
Should never be employ'd. Welcome Menippus.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I have found her ſir,
I meane the place ſhe is lodg'd in; her name is Celia,
And much a doe I had to purchaſe that too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Doſt think Demetrius loves her?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Much I feare it,
But nothing that way yet can win for certaine.
Ile tell your grace within this houre.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A ſtranger?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: VVithout all doubt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But how ſhould he come to her?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: There lies the marrow of the matter hid yet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Has't thou been with thy wife?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: No ſir, I am going to her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Goe and diſpatch, and meet me in the garden,
And get all out ye can. Exit.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Ile doe my beſt ſir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Bleſt be thy wife, thou wert an arrant aſſe elſe.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I, ſhe is a ſtirring woman indeed:
There's a braine brother.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: There's not a handſome wench of any mettle
VVithin an hundred miles, but her intelligence
Reaches her, and out reaches her, and brings her
As confidently to Court, as to a ſanctuary:
VVhat had his mouldy braines ever arriv'd at,
Had not ſhe beaten it out oth' Flint to faſten him?
They ſay ſhe keeps an office of Concealements:
There is no young wench, let her be a Saint,
Unleſſe ſhe live ith' Center, but ſhe findes her,
And every way prepares addreſſes to her:
If my wife would have followed her courſe Charinthus,
Her lucky courſe, I had the day before him:
O what might I have been by this time, Brother?
But ſhe (forſooth) when I put theſe things to her,
Theſe things of honeſt thrift, groans, ô my conſcience,
The load upon my conſcience, when to make us cuckolds,
They have no more burthen then a brood-gooſe, brother;
But let's doe what we can, though this wench faile us,
Another of a new way will be lookt at:
Come, let's abroad, and beat our brains, time may
For all his wiſedome, yet give us a day. Ex.

div.head: Scaene. 2.
div.stage: Drum within, Allarme, Enter Demetrius and Leontius.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I will not ſee 'em fall thus, give me way ſir,
I ſhall forget you love me elſe.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: VVill ye loſe all?
For me to be forgotten, to be hated,
Nay never to have been a man, is nothing,
So you, and thoſe we have preſerv'd from ſlaughter
Come ſafely off.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I have loſt my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You are cozn'd.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And am moſt miſerable.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: There's no man ſo, but he that makes himſelf ſo.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I will goe on.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You muſt not: I ſhall tell you then,
And tell you true, that man's unfit to governe,
That cannot guide himſelfe: you lead an Army?
That have not ſo much manly ſuff'rance left yee,
To beare a loſſe?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Charge but once more Leontius,
My friends and my companions are engag'd all.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Nay give 'em loſt, I ſaw 'em off their horſes,
And the enemy maſter of their Armes; nor could then,
The policie, nor ſtrength of man redeem 'em.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And ſhall I know this, and ſtand fooling?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: By my dead fathers ſoule you ſtir not, ſir,
Or if you doe, you make your way through me firſt.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thou art a Coward.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: To prevent a Madman.
None but your fathers Son, durſt call me ſo,
'Death if he did—Muſt I be ſcandall'd by ye,
That hedg'd in all the helps I had to ſave ye?
That, where there was a valiant weapon ſtirring,
Both ſearch'd it out, and ſingl'd it, unedg'd it,
For feare it ſhould bite you, am I a coward?
Goe, get ye up, and tell 'em ye are the Kings Sonne;
Hang all your Ladies favours on your Creſt,
And let them fight their ſhares; ſpurre to deſtruction,
You cannot miſſe the way: be bravely deſperate,
And your young friends before ye, that loſt this battell,
Your honourable friends, that knew no order,
Cry out, Antigonus, the old Antigonus,
The wiſe and fortunate Antigonus,
The great, the valiant, and the fear'd Antigenus,
Has ſent a deſperate ſonne, without diſcretion
To bury in an houre his age of honor.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I am aſhamed.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 'Tis ten to one, I die with ye:
The coward will not long be after ye;
I ſcorne to ſay I ſaw you fall, ſigh for ye,
And tell a whining tale, ſome ten yeares after
To boyes and girles in an old chimney corner,
Of what a Prince we had, how bravely ſpirited;
How young and faire he fell: wee'l all goe with ye,
And ye ſhall ſee us all, like ſacrifices
In our beſt trim, fill up the mouth of ruine,
Will this faith ſatisfie your folly? can this ſhow ye,
Tis not to die we feare, but to die poorely,
To fall, forgotten, in a multitude?
If you will needs tempt fortune now ſhe has held ye,
Held ye from ſinking up.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Pray doe not kill me,
Theſe words pierce deeper then the wounds I ſuffer,
The ſmarting wounds of loſſe.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ye are too tender;
Fortune has houres of loſſe, and houres of honor,
And the moſt valiant feele them both: take comfort,
The next is ours, I have a ſoule deſcries it:
The angry bull never goes backe for breath,
But when he meanes to arme his fury double.
Let this day ſet but not the memorie,
And we ſhall find a time: How now Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I know not: I am mall'd: we are bravely beaten,
All our young gallants loſt.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thou art hurt.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I am pepper'd,
I was i'th' midſt of all: and bang'd of all hands:
They made an anvile of my head, it rings yet;
Never ſo threſh'd: do you call this fame? I have fam'd it;
I have got immortall fame, but I'le no more on't;
I'le no ſuch ſcratching Saint to ſerve hereafter;
O my conſcience I was kill'd above twenty times,
And yet I know not what a Devil's in't,
I crawled away, and lived againe ſtill; I am hurt plaguily,
But now I have nothing neere ſo much paine Colonell,
They have ſliced me for that maladie.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: All the young men loſt?

sp.speaker: Lie.
sp.l: I am glad you are here: but they are all i'th' pound ſir,
They'l never ride o're other mens corne againe, I take it,
Such frisking, and ſuch flaunting with their feathers,
And ſuch careering with their miſtres favours;
And here muſt he be pricking out for honor,
And there got he a knocke, and downe goes pilgarlike,
Commends his ſoule to his ſhe-ſaint, and exit.
Another ſpurres in there, cryes make roome villaines,
I am a Lord, ſcarce ſpoken, but with reverence
A raſcall takes him o're the face, and fels him;
There lyes the Lord, the Lord be with him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Now ſir,
Doe you find this truth?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I would not.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Pox upon it,
They have ſuch tender bodies too; ſuch Culliſſes,
That one good hanſome blow breaks 'em a pieces.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How ſtands the Enemie?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Even coole enough too:
For to ſay truth, he has bin ſhrewdly heated,
The gentleman no doubt will fall to his jewlips.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He marches not i'th' taile on's.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: No, plague take him,
Hee'l kiſſe our tailes as ſoone; he lookes upon us,
As if he would ſay, if ye will turne againe, friends,
We will belabor you a little better,
And beat a little more care into your coxcombs.
Now ſhall we have damnable Ballads out againſt us,
Moſt wicked madrigals: and ten to one Colonell,
Sung to ſuch lowſie, lamentable tunes.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thou art merrie,
How e're the game goes: good ſir be not troubled,
A better day will draw this backe againe.
Pray goe, and cheere thoſe left, and lead 'em off,
They are hot, and wearie.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I'le doe any thing.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Lieutenant, ſend one preſentlie away
To 'th' King, and let him know our ſtate: and harke ye,
Be ſure the meſſenger adviſe his Majeſtie
To comfort up the Prince: hee's full of ſadnes.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: When ſhall I get a Surgeon? this hot weather,
Unleſſe I be well pepper'd, I ſhall ſtinke Colonel.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Goe, I'le prepare thee one.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: If ye catch me then,
Fighting againe, I'le eat hay with a horſe. Ex.

div.head: Scaene 3.
div.stage: Enter Leucippe (reading) and two Maids at a Table, writing.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Have ye written to Merione?

sp.speaker: 1. Ma.
sp.l: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: And let her underſtand the hopes ſhe has
If ſhe come ſpeedilie —

sp.speaker: 1. Ma.
sp.l: All theſe are ſpecified,

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: And of the chaine is ſent her,
And the rich ſtuffe to make her ſhew more hanſome here?

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.l: All this is done, Madam.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: What have you diſpatcht there?

sp.speaker: 2 Mai.
sp.l: A letter to the Countrey maid, and't pleaſe ye.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: A pretty girle, but peeviſh, plaguy peeviſh:
Have ye bought the embroydered gloves, and that purſe for her,
And the new Curle?

sp.speaker: 2. Maid.
sp.l: They are ready packt up Madam.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Her maiden-head will yeeld me; let me ſee now,
She is not fifteen they ſay: for her complexion—
Cloe, Cloe, Cloe, here, I have her,
Cloe, the Daughter of a Countrey gentleman;
Her age upon fifteen: now her complexion,
A lovely browne; here 'tis; eyes black and rolling,
The body neatly built: ſhe ſtrikes a Lute well,
Sings moſt inticingly: theſe helpes conſider'd,
Her maiden-head will amount to ſome three hundred,
Or three hundred & fifty crowns; 'twil bear it handſomly.
Her father's poore, ſome little ſhare deducted,
To buy him a hunting Nag; I, 'twill be pretty:
VVho takes care of the Merchants wife?

sp.speaker: 1 Mai.
sp.l: I have wrought her.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: You know for whom ſhe is?

sp.speaker: 1. Maid.
sp.l: Very well, Madam,
Though very much adoe, I had to make her
Apprehend that happineſſe.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Theſe kinde are ſubtile:
Did ſhe not cry and blubber when ye urg'd her.

sp.speaker: 1. Maid.
sp.p: O moſt extremly, & ſwore ſhe would rather periſh.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Good ſignes, very good ſignes,
Symptomes of eaſie nature.
Had ſhe the plate?

sp.speaker: 1. Maid.
sp.l: She lookt upon't, and left it,
And turn'd againe, and view'd it.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Very well ſtill.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.l: At length ſhe was content to let it lye there,
Till I call'd for't, or ſo,

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: She will come?

sp.speaker: 1. Maid.
sp.l: Doe you take me
For ſuch a foole, I would part without that promiſe?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: The Chambers next the park.

sp.speaker: 2. Maid.
sp.l: The Widdow Madam,
You bad me look upon.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Hang her, ſhe is muſtic:
She is no mans meat; beſide, ſhe is poore and ſluttiſh:
Where lies old Thisbe now, you are ſo ſo long now—

sp.speaker: 2. Ma.
sp.l: Thisbe, Thisbe, This. agent Thisbe, ô I have her,
She lyes now in Nicopolis.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Diſpatch a packet,
And tell her, her ſuperiour here commands her,
The next Mon'th not to faile, but ſee deliver'd
Here to our uſe, ſome twenty young and handſome,
As alſo able maids, for the Court ſervice,
As ſhe will anſwer it: we are out of beautie,
Utterly out, and rub the time away here,
With ſuch blown ſtuff, I am aſham'd to ſend it. Knock within.
Who's that? look out, to your buſineſſe maid,
There's nothing got by idleneſſe: There is a Lady,
Which if I can but buckle with, Altea,
A, A, A, A, Altea, young, and marrried,
And a great lover of her husband, well,
Not to be brought to Court: ſay ye ſo? I am ſorry,
The Court ſhall be brought to you then: how now, who is't?

sp.speaker: 1. Maid.
sp.l: An ancient woman, with a maid attending,
A pretty girle, but out of cloathes; for a little money,
It ſeemes ſhe would put her to your bringing up, Madam,

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Let her come in. Would ye ought with us, good woman?
I pray be ſhort, we are full of buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: I have a tender girle here, and't pleaſe your honour.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: VVom.
sp.l: That hath a great deſire to ſerve your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: It may be ſo; I am full of Maids.

sp.speaker: VVom.
sp.l: She is young, forſooth—
And for her truth; and as they ſay her bearing.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Ye ſay well: come ye hither maid, let me feel your pulſe,
'Tis ſome what weak, but nature will grow ſtronger,
Let me ſee your leg, ſhe treads but low ith' paſternes.

sp.speaker: VVom.
sp.l: A cork heele Madam.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: We know what will doe it,
Without your aime good woman: what do you pitch her at?
Shee's but a ſlight toy—cannot hold out long.

sp.speaker: VVom.
sp.l: Even what you think is meet.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Give her ten Crowns, we are full of buſineſſe,
Shee is a poore woman, let her take a Cheeſe home:
Enter the wench ith' office. Ex. VVom. & 1. Mai.

sp.speaker: 2. Maid.
sp.l: What's your name, ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Phebe forſooth.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: A pretty name; 'twill doe well:
Goe in, and let the other maid inſtruct ye Phebe; Ex. Phe.
Let my old velvet skirt be made fit for her,
I'le put her into action for a waſcoate,
And when I have rigg'd her up once, this ſmall Pinnace
Shall ſaile for gold, and good ſtore too: who's there? Knock within. Ent. Menippe.
Lord, ſhall we never have any eaſe in this world?
Still troubled? ſtill moleſted? what would you have?
I cannot furniſh ye faſter then I am able
And ye were my husband a thouſand times, I cannot do it;
At leaſt a dozen poaſts are gone this morning
For ſeverall parts of the Kingdome: I can do no more
But pay 'em, and inſtruct 'em.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Prethee, good ſweet heart,
I come not to diſturbe thee, nor diſcourage thee,
I know thou labour'ſt truly: harke in thine eare.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Ha?
What do you make ſo dainty on't? looke there,
I am an Aſſe, I can do nothing.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I, this is ſhe; a ſtranger borne.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: What would you give for more now?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Prethee, my beſt Leucippe, ther's much hangs ont
Lodg'd at the end of Marse's ſtreet? thats true too;
At the ſacke of ſuch a Towne, by ſuch a Souldier
Preſerv'd a priſoner: and by Prince Demetrius
Bought from that man againe, maintain'd, and favourd:
How came you by this knowledge?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Poore weake man,
I have a thouſand eyes, when thou art ſleeping,
Abroad, and full of buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: You never tri'd her?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: No, ſhe is beyond my levell; ſo hedg'd in
By the Princes infinite love, and favour to her—

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: She is a hanſome wench.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: A delicate, and knowes it;
And out of that proofe armes her ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Come in then;
I have a great deſigne from the King to you,
And you muſt worke like waxe now.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: On this Lady?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: On this, and all your wits call home.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I have done.
Toyes in my time of ſome note; old as I am,
I thinke my braines will worke without barme,
Take up the Bookes.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: As we goe in, I'le tell ye. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaene 4.
div.stage: Enter Antigonus, Tymon, Lords, and a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No face of ſorrow for this loſſe? 'twill choake him,
Nor no man miſſe a friend, I know his nature
So deep impreſt with griefe, for what he has ſuffer'd,
That the leaſt adding to it, adds to his ruine;
His loſſe is not ſo infinite, I hope Souldier.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Faith neither great, nor out of diſcretion,
The young men out of heate.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I gheſſe the manner.

sp.speaker: Lord Men.
sp.l: The Prince and't like your Grace—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You are welcome home ſir;
Come, no more ſorrow, I have heard your fortune,
And I my ſelf haue tride the like: cleare up man,
I will not have ye take it thus; if I doubted.
Your feare had loſt; and that you had turn'd your back to 'em,
Baſely beſought their mercies—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: No, no, by this hand ſir,
We fought like honeſt and tall men.

sp.speaker: Antig.
sp.l: I know't Leontius; or if I thought
Neglect of rule, having his councell with ye,
Or too vaine-glorious appetite of fame,
Your men forgot, and ſcatter'd.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: None of theſe ſir,
He ſhew'd himſelfe a noble gentleman,
Every way apt to rule.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Theſe being granted;
Why ſhould you think you have done an act ſo hainous,
That nought but diſcontent dwells round about ye?
I have loſt a Battaile.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I, and fought it hard too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: With as much meanes as man—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Or devill could urge it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Twenty to one of our ſide now.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Turne Tables,
Beaten like dogs againe, like Owles, you take it
To hart for flying but a mile before 'em,
And to ſay truth, 'twas no flight neither ſir,
'Twas but a walke, a handſome walke,
I have tumbl'd with this old body, beaten like a ſtock-fiſh,
And ſtuck with arrowes, like an arming Quiver,
Blouded and bang'd, almoſt a day before 'em,
And glad I have got off then. Here's a mad ſhaver,
He fights his ſhare I am ſure, when ere he comes to't;
Yet I have ſeen him trip it tithely too,
And cry the devill take the hindmoſt ever.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I learn'd it of my betters.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Boudge at this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Has fortune but one face?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: In her beſt vizard,
Me thinks ſhe looks but lowzily.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Chance, though ſhe faint now,
And ſink below our expectations,
Is there no hope left ſtrong enough to boy her?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: 'Tis not this day, I fled before the enemie,
And loſt my people, left mine honour murder'd,
My mayden honour, never to be ranſom'd,
(VVhich to a noble ſoule is too too ſencible)
Afflicts me with this ſadneſſe; moſt of theſe,
Time may turne ſtraight againe, experience perfect,
And new ſwords, cut new wayes to nobler fortunes.
O I have loſt—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: As you are mine forget it:
I doe not think it loſſe.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.l: O ſir, forgive me,
I have loſt my friends, thoſe worthy ſoules bred with me,
I have loſt my ſelfe, they were the pieces of me;
I have loſt all Arts, my Schooles are taken from me,
Honour and Armes, no emulation left me:
I liv'd to ſee theſe men loſt, look'd upon it;
Theſe men that twin'd their loves to mine, their vertues,
O ſhame of ſhames, I ſaw, and could not ſave 'em,
This carries ſulphure in't, this burnes and boyles me,
And like a fatall Tombe beſtrides my memorie.

sp.speaker: Antig.
sp.l: This was hard fortune, but if alive, and taken,
They ſhall be ranſom'd; let it be at Millions.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: They are dead, they are dead.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: VVhen would he weep for me thus?
I may be dead, and powder'd.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Good Prince, grieve not:
VVe are not certaine of their deaths: the enemy,
Though he be hot, and keene,
Yet holds good Quarter.
VVhat noyſe is this?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: He doe's not follow us?
Give me a ſteeple top.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: They live, they live ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hold up your manly face;
They live, they are here, Son.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Theſe are the men.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: They are, and live to honour ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: How ſcap't ye noble friends? me thought I ſaw ye
Even in the jawes of death.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: Thanks to our folly,
That ſpurr'd us on; we were indeed hedg'd round in't,
And ev'n beyond the hand of ſuccour beaten,
Unhors'd, diſarm'd: and what we lookt for then ſir,
Let ſuch poore weary ſoules that heare the Bell knoll,
And ſee the grave a digging, tell.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: For heaven ſake
Delude mine eyes no longer: how came ye off?

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: Againſt all expectation: the brave Seleucus,
I thinke this day enamour'd on your vertue,
VVhen, through the Troops, he ſaw ye ſhoot like lightning;
And at your manly courage all tooke fire,
And after that, the miſerie we fell too,
The never-certaine fate of war conſidering,
As we ſtood all before him, fortunes ruines,
Nothing but death expecting, a ſhort time
He made a ſtand upon our youths and fortunes,
Then with an eye of mercy inform'd his judgement,
How yet unripe we were, unblowne, unhardend,
Unfitted for ſuch fatall ends; he cryed out to us,
Goe Gentlemen, commend me to your Maſter,
To the moſt high, and hopefull prince Demetrius,
Tell him the valour that he ſhowed againſt me
This day, the virgin valour, and true fire
Deſerves, even from an Enemie, this courteſie;
Your lives and Armes freely I'le give 'em: thanke him,
And thus we are return'd Sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Faith 'twas well done;
'Twas bravely done; was't not a noble part Sir?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Had I been there up had I gone, I am ſure on't;
Theſe noble tricks, I never durſt truſt 'em yet.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Let me not live, and't were not a famed honeſtie,
It takes me ſuch a tickling way: now would I wiſh heaven,
But ee'n the happines, ee'n that poore bleſſing
For all the ſharp afflictions thou haſt ſent me,
But ee'n i'th' head o'th' field to take Seleucus.
I ſhould doe ſomething memorable: fie, ſad ſtill.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: Doe you grieve we are come off?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Unranſom'd, was it?

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: It was ſir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And with ſuch a fame to me?
Said ye not ſo?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ye have heard it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: O Leontius,
Better I had loſt 'em all: my ſelfe had periſhed,
And all my fathers hopes,

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Mercy upon ye,
VVhat ayle ye Sir? 'death, doe not make fooles on's,
Neither goe to Church, nor tarry at home,
That's a fine Horne-pipe?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: VVhat's now your griefe Demetrius?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Did he not beat us twice?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He beate a pudding;
Beate us but once.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Has beate me twice, and beat me to a coward,
Beat me to nothing.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Is not the devill in him?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I pray it be no worſe.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Twice conquer'd me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Bear witneſſe all the world, I am a dunce here.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: With valour firſt he ſtrook me, then with honour;
That ſtroak Leontius, that ſtrook, do'ſt thou not feele it?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Where abouts was it? for I remember nothing yet.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: All theſe gentlemen
That were his priſoners—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Yes, he ſet 'em free ſir,
With Armes and honour.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: There, there, now thou haſt it;
At mine owne weapon, Courteſie, h'as beaten me,
At that I was held a Maſter in, he has cow'd me,
Hotter then all the dint oth' fight he has charg'd me:
Am I not now a wretched fellow? think on't;
And when thou haſt examin'd all wayes honourable,
And find'ſt no doore left open to requite this,
Conclude I am a wretch, and was twice beaten.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have obſerv'd your way, and underſtand it,
And equall love it as Demetrius,
My noble childe thou ſhalt not fall in vertue,
I and my power will ſink firſt: you Leontius,
Wait for a new Commiſſion, ye ſhall out againe,
And inſtantly: you ſhall not lodge this night here,
Not ſee a friend, nor take a bleſſing with ye,
Before ye be ith'field: the enemy is up ſtill,
And ſtill in ful dnſigne: Charge him againe, Son,
And either bring home that againe thou haſt loſt there,
Or leave thy body by him.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Ye raiſe me,
And now I dare look up againe, Leontius.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I, I, ſir, I am thinking who we ſhall take of 'em,
To make all ſtraight; and who we ſhall give toth' devill.
VVhat ſaiſt thou now Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I ſay nothing.
Lord what aile I, that I have no minde to fight now?
I finde my conſtitution mightily alter'd
Since I came home: I hate all noiſes too,
Eſpecially the noiſe of Drums; I am now as well
As any living man; why not as valiant?
To fight now, is a kinde of vomit to me,
It goes againſt my ſtomack.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Good ſir, preſently;
You cannot doe your Son, ſo faire a favour.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis my intent: Ile ſee ye march away too;
Come, get your men together preſently, Leontius,
And preſſe where pleaſe you, as you march.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: VVe goe ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: VVait you on me, Ile bring ye to your command,
And then to fortune give you up.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Ye love me. Ext.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Goe, get the drums, beat round, Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Harke ye, ſir,
I have a fooliſh buſineſſe they call marriage.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: After the wars are done.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: The partie ſtaies ſir,
I have giv'n the Prieſt his money too: all my friends ſir,
My father, and my mother.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: VVill you goe forward?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: She brings a pretty matter with her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Halfe a dozen Baſtards.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Some fortie ſir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A goodly competency.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I meane ſir, pounds a year; Ile diſpatch the matter,
'Tis but a night or two; Ile overtake ye ſir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: The 2 old legions, yes: where lies the horſe-quarter?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: And if it be a boy, Ile even make bold ſir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Away with your whore,
A plague o'your whore, you damn'd rogue,
Now ye are cur'd and well; muſt ye be clicketing?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I have broke my minde to my Ancient, in my abſence,
Hee's a ſufficient gentleman.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Get forward.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Onely receive her portion.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Get ye forward;
Elſe Ile bang ye forward.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Strange ſir,
A Gentleman and an officer cannot have the libertie
To doe the office of a man.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Shame light on thee,
How came this whore into thy head?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: This whore ſir?
'Tis ſtrange, a poore whore.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Doe not anſwer me:
Troop, Troop away; doe not name this whore againe,
Or think there is a whore.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: That's very hard ſir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: For if thou doſt, look to't, Ile have thee guelded,
Ile walk ye out before me: not a word more. Ex.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Ye are the Miſtris of the houſe ye ſay,
Where this young Ladie lies.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: For want of a better.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: You may be good enough for ſuch a purpoſe:
When was the Prince with her? anſwer me directly.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: Not ſince he went a warring.

sp.speaker: Leuc.
sp.l: Very well then:
What carnall copulation are you privie too
Between theſe two? be not afraid, we are women,
And may talke thus amongſt our ſelves, no harme in't.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: No ſure, there's no harme in't, I conceive that;
But truely, that I ever knew the gentlewoman
Otherwiſe given, then a hopefull gentlewoman—

sp.speaker: Leuc.
sp.l: You'll grant me the Prince loves her?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: There I am with ye.
And the gods bleſſe her, promiſes her mightily.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Stay there a while. And gives her gifts?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Extreamly;
And truely makes a very Saint of her.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I ſhould think now,
(Good woman let me have your judgement with me,
I ſee 'tis none of the worſt: Come ſit down by me)
That theſe two cannot love ſo tenderly.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Being ſo young as they are too.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: You ſay well—
But that methinks ſome further promiſes —

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Yes, yes,
I have heard the Prince ſweare he would marry her.

sp.speaker: Leuc.
sp.l: Verie well ſtill: they doe not uſe to fall out?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: The tendereſt Chickens to one another,
They cannot live an houre aſſunder.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I have done then;
And be you gone; you know your charge, and doe it.
You know whoſe will it is; if you tranſgreſſe it—
That is, if any have acceſſe, or ſee her,
Before the Kings will be fulfill'd—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Not the Prince, Madam?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: You'll be hang'd if you it, that Ile aſſure ye.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: But ne're the leſſe, Ile make bold to obey ye.

sp.speaker: Leuc.
sp.l: Away, and to your buſineſſe then.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: 'Tis done, Madam. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: THou haſt taken wondrous pains; but yet Menippus,
You underſtand not of what bloud, & countrey.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I labour'd that, but cannot come to know it.
A Greek I am ſure ſhe is, ſhe ſpeaks this language.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is ſhe ſo excellent handſome?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Moſt inticing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sold for a priſoner?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Yes ſir,
Some poore creature.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And he loves tenderly?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: They ſay extreamly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis well prevented then: yes, I perceiv'd it:
When he took leave now, he made a hundred ſtops,
Deſir'd an houre, but halfe an houre, a minute,
Which I with anger croſs'd; I knew his buſineſſe,
I knew 'twas ſhe he hunted on; this journey, man,
I beat out ſuddenly for her cauſe intended,
And would not give him time to breath. When comes ſhe?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: This morning ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Lodge her to all delight then:
For I would have her try'd toth' teſt: I know,
She muſt be ſome crackt coyne, not fit his traffique,
Which when we have found, the ſhame will make him leave her,
Or we ſhal work a nearer way: Ile bury him,
And with him all the hopes I have caſt upon him,
Ere he ſhall dig his owne grave in that woman:
You know which way to bring her: Ile ſtand cloſe there,
To view her as ſhe paſſes: and doe you hear Menippus,
Obſerve her with all ſweetneſſe: humour her,
'Twill make her lie more careleſſe to our purpoſes.
Away, and take what helpes you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I am gone ſir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Governeſſe, from whom was this Gown ſent me?
Prethee be ſerious true; I will not wear't elſe:
'Tis a handſome one.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: As though you know not?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No faith:
But I believe, for certaine too, yet I wonder,
Becauſe it was his caution, this poore way,
Still to preſerve me from the curious ſearchings
Of greedy eyes.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You have it: does it pleaſe you?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis very rich, methinks too, prethee tell me?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: From one that likes you wel, never look coy, Lady;
Theſe are no gifts, to be put off with poutings.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Powtings, and gifts? is it from any ſtranger?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You are ſo curious, that there is no talk to ye.
What if it be I pray ye?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Unpin good Governeſſe,
Quick, quick.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Quick, good Governeſſe:
Fie on't, how beaſtly it becomes me? poorely?
A trick put in upon me? well ſaid Governeſſe:
I vow I would not weare it—out, it ſmells muſty.
Are theſe your tricks? now I begin to ſmell it
Abominable muſty; will ye help me?
The Prince will come againe—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You are not mad ſure?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: As I live ile cut it off: a pox upon it;
For ſure it was made for that uſe; do you bring me Livories?
Stales to catch Kites? doſt thou laugh too, thou baſe woman?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I cannot chuſe, if I ſhould be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Abuſe me,
And then laugh at me too?

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: I doe not abuſe ye:
Is it abuſe, to give him drink that's thirſty?
You want cloathes; is it ſuch a hainous ſin I beſeech ye,
To ſee you ſtor'd?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: There is no greater wickedneſſe
Then this way.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: What way?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I ſhall curſe thee fearefully,
If thou provok'ſt me further: and take heed, woman;
My curſes never miſſe.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Curſe him that ſent it.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Tell but his name—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You dare not curſe him.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Dare not?
By this faire light—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You are ſo full of paſſion—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Dare not be good? be honeſt? dare not curſe him?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I think you dare not: I beleeve ſo.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Speak him.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Up with your valour then, up with it bravely,
And take your full charge.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: If I doe not, hang me;
Tell but his name.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: 'Twas Prince Demetrius ſent it:
Now, now, give fire, kill him ith' eye now Lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Is he come home?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: It ſeems ſo; but your curſe now.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: You doe not lie, I hope.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You dare not curſe him.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Prethee do not abuſe me: is he come home indeed?
For I would now with all my heart beleeve thee.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Nay, you may chuſe: alas, I deale for ſtrangers,
That ſend ye ſcurvie muſty Gownes, ſtale Livories:
I have my tricks.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis a good gowne, a handſome one;
I did but jeſt; where is he?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: He that ſent it—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How? he that ſent it? is't come to that againe?
Thou canſt not be ſo fooliſh: prethee ſpeak out,
I may miſtake thee.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I ſaid he that ſent it.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Curſe o' my life: why doſt thou vex me thus?
I know thou meanſt Demetrius, doſt thou not?
I charge thee ſpeak truth: if it be any other,
Thou knowſt the charge he gave thee, and the juſtice
His anger will inflict, if 'ere he know this,
As know he ſhall, he ſhall, thou ſpightfull woman,
Thou beaſtly woman; and thou ſhalt know too late too,
And feele too ſenſible, I am no ward,
No ſale ſtuffe for your money Merchants that ſent it?
Who dare ſend me, or how durſt thou, thou—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: What you pleaſe:
For this is ever the reward of ſervice.
The Prince ſhall bring the next himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis ſtrange
That you ſhould deale ſo peeviſhly: beſhrew ye,
You have put me in a heat.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I am ſure ye have kild me:
I ne're receiv'd ſuch language: I can but wait upon ye,
And be your drudge; keep a poore life to ſerve ye.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You know my nature is too eaſie, Governeſſe,
And you know now, I am ſorry too: how does he?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: O God, my head.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Prethee be wel, and tell me,
Did he ſpeak of me, ſince he came? nay, ſee now,
If thou wilt leave this tyranny? good ſweet governeſſe,
Did he but name his Celia? look upon me,
Upon my faith I meant no harme: here, take this,
And buy thy ſelfe ſome rrifles: did a good wench?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: He loves yee but too dearely.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: That's my good Governeſſe.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: There's more cloathes making for yee.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: More cloathes?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: More:
Richer and braver; I can tell yee that newes;
And twenty glorious things.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: To what uſe ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Ye are too good for our houſe now: we poore wretches
Shall loſe the comfort of ye.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No, I hope not.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: For ever loſe ye Lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Loſe me? wherefore?
I heare of no ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: 'Tis ſure it muſt be ſo:
You muſt ſhine now at Court: ſuch preparation,
Such hurrie, and ſuch hanging roomes—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Toth' Court wench?
Was it toth' Court thou ſaidſt?

sp.speaker: Gox.
sp.l: You'll finde it ſo.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Staie, ſtay, this cannot be.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I ſay it muſt be:
I hope to finde ye ſtill the ſame good Lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Toth' Court? this ſtumbles me: art ſure for me, wench,
This preparation is?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: She is peilous crafty:
I feare too honeſt for us all too. Am I ſure I live?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Toth' Court? this cannot down: what ſhould I do there?
Why ſhould he on a ſuddain change his mind thus,
And not make me acquainted? ſure he loves me;
His vow was made againſt it, and mine with him:
At leaſt while this King liv'd: he will come hither,
And ſee me ere I goe?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Wou'd ſome wiſe woman
Had her in working: that I think he will not,
Becauſe he means with all joy there to meet ye.
Ye ſhall heare more within this houre?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: A Courtier?
What may that meaning be? ſure he will ſee me
If he be come, he muſt: Hark ye good Governeſſe,
What age is the King of?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Hee's an old man, and full of buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I feare too full indeed: what Ladies are there?
I would be loath to want good company.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Delicate young Ladies, as you would deſire;
And when you are acquainted, the beſt company.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis very well: prethee goe in, let's talk more.
For though I feare a trick, Ile bravely try it.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I ſee he muſt be cunning,
Knoks this Doe downe. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You ſhal not have your wil, ſirrah, are ye running?
Have ye gotten a toy in your heeles? Is this a ſeaſon,
When honour pricks ye on, to prick your eares up,
After your whore, your Hobby-horſe?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Why look ye now:
What a ſtrange man are you? would you have a man fight
At all houres all alike.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Doe but fight ſomething;
But halfe a blow, and put thy ſtomack to't:
Turne but thy face, and do but make mouthes at 'em.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: And have my teeth knockt out; I thank ye heartily,
Ye are my deare friend.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What a devill ailes thee?
Doſt long to be hang'd?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Faith Sir, I make no ſuit for't:
But rather then I would live thus our of charity,
Continually in brawling—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Art thou not he?
I may be cozn'd—

sp.speaker: Lie.
sp.l: I ſhall be diſcover'd.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: That in the midſt of thy moſt helliſh pains,
When thou wert crawling ſick, didſt aime at wonders,
When thou wert mad with paine?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Ye have found the cauſe out;
I had ne're been mad to fight elſe: I confeſſe ſir,
The dayly torture of my ſide that vext me,
Made me as dayly careleſſe what became of me,
Till a kinde ſword there wounded me, and eas'd me;
'Twas nothing in my valour fought; I am well now,
And take ſome pleaſure in my life, methinks now,
It ſhewes as mad a thing to me to ſee you ſcuffle,
And kill one another fooliſhly for honour,
As 'twas to you, to ſee me play the cox-combe.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And wilt thou ne're fight more?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Ith' minde I am in,

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Nor never be ſick againe?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I hope I ſhall not.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Prethee be ſick againe; prethee, I beſeech thee,
Be juſt ſo ſick againe.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Ile juſt be hang'd firſt.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: If all the Arts that are can make a Chollique,
Therefore look to't: or if impoſthumes, marke me,
As big as foot-bals—

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Deliver me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Or ſtones of ten pound weight ith' kidneyes,
Through eaſe and ugly dyets may be gather'd;
Ile feed ye up my ſelfe ſir, Ile prepare ye,
You cannot fight, unleſſe the devill teare ye,
You ſhall not want provocations, Ile ſcratch ye,
Ile have thee have the tooth-ach, and the head-ach.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Good Colonell, Ile doe any thing.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: No, no, nothing—
Then will I have thee blowne with a paire of Smiths bellowes,
Becauſe ye ſhall be ſure to have a round gale with ye,
Fil'd full of oyle, o' devill, and Aqua fortis,
And let theſe worke, theſe may provoke.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Good Colonell.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A coward in ful bloud; prethee be plain with me,
Will roaſting doe thee any good?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Nor baſting neither, ſir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Marry that goes hard. Enter 1. Gent.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Where are you Colonell?
The Prince expects ye ſir; has hedg'd the enemy
Within a ſtraight, where all the hopes and valours
Of all men living cannot force a paſſage,
He has 'em now.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I knew all this before ſir,
I chalk'd him out his way: but do you ſee that thing there?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Nay good ſweet Colonell, Ile fight a little.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: That thing?

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: What thing? I ſee the brave Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Rogue, what a name haſt thou loſt?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: You may helpe it?
Yet you may help't: Ile doe ye any courteſie:
I know you love a wench well. Enter 2 Gent.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Look upon him;
Doe you look too.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: What ſhould I look on?
I come to tell yee, the Prince ſtayes your direction,
We have 'em now ith Coop, ſir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Let 'em reſt there,
And chew upon their miſeries: but look firſt—

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I cannot fight for all this.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Look on this fellow.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: I know him; 'tis the valiant brave Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Canſt thou heare this, and play the rogue? ſteal off quickly,
Behinde me quickly, neatly doe it,
And ruſh into the thickeſt of the enemy,
And if thou kill'ſt but two.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: You may excuſe me,
'Tis not my fault: I dare not fight.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Be rul'd yet
Ile beat thee on; goe wink and fight: a plague upon your ſheeps heart.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: What's all this matter?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Nay I cannot ſhew yee.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Here's twenty pound, goe but ſmell to 'em.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Alas ſir,
I have taken ſuch a cold I can ſmell nothing.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I can ſmell a raſcall, a ranke raſcall:
Fye, how he ſtinks, ſtinkes like a tyred Jade.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: What ſir?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Why, that ſir, doe not you ſmell him?

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: Smell him?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I muſt endure.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Stinks like a dead dog, Carrion—
There's no ſuch damnable ſmell under heaven,
As the faint ſweat of a Coward: will ye fight yet?

sp.speaker: Lie.
sp.l: Nay, now I defie ye; ye have ſpoke the worſt, ye can
Of me, and if every man ſhould take what you ſay
To the heart. —

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: God a mercy,
God a mercy with all my heart; here I forgive thee;
And fight, or fight not, doe but goe along with us,
And keep my dog.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I love a good dog naturally.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: What's all this ſtir, Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.l: Nothing Sir,
But a ſlight matter of argument.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Pox take thee.
Sure I ſhall love this rogue, he's ſo pretty a Coward,
Come gentlemen, let's up now, and if fortune
Dare play the ſlut againe, Ile never more Saint her,
Come play fellow, come, prethee come up; come chicken,
I have a way ſhall fit yet: A tame knave.
Come, look upon us.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Ile tell ye who does beſt boyes. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I ſaw her comming out,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: VVho waits upon her?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Tymon, Charinthus, and ſome other gentlemen,
By me appointed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: VVhere's your wife?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Shee's ready
To entertaine her here ſir; and ſome Ladies
Fit for her lodgings.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How ſhews ſhe in her trim now?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Oh moſt divinely ſweet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Prethee ſpeak ſoftly.
How does ſhe take her comming?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: She beares it bravely;
But what ſhe thinks—I or heaven ſake ſir preserve me—
If the Prince chance to finde this.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Peace ye old foole;
She thinks to meet him here.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: That's all the Project.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: VVas ſhe hard to bring?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: No, ſhe believ'd it quickly,
And quickly made her ſelfe fit, the Gowne a little,
And thoſe new things ſhe has not been acquainted with,
At leaſt in this place, where ſhe liv'd a priſoner,
Troubled and ſtirr'd her minde, But believe me ſir,
She has worne as good, they ſit ſo apted to her;
And ſhe is ſo great a Miſtris of diſpoſure:
Here they come now: but take a full view of her.
sp.stage: Enter Celia, Tymon, Charinthus, and Gent.
sp.l: How cheerefully ſhe looks? how ſhe ſalutes all?
And how ſhe viewes the place? ſhe is very yong ſure:
That was an admirable ſmile, a catching one,
The very twang of Cupids bow ſung to it:
She has two-edg'd eyes, they kill o' both ſides.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: She makes a ſtand, as though ſhe would ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Be ſtill then.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Good Gentlemen, trouble your ſelves no further,
I had thought ſure to have met a noble friend here.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Yee may meet many Lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Such as you are
I covet few or none, ſir.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: VVill you walk this way,
And take the ſweets oth' garden? coole and cloſe, Lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Methinks this open aire's farre better, tend ye that way.
Pray where's the woman came along?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: VVhat woman?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: The woman of the houſe I lay at.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Woman?
Here was none came along ſure.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sure I am catcht then:
Pray where's the Prince?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: He will not be long from yee,
We are his humble ſervants.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I could laugh now,
To ſee how finely I am cozn'd: yet I feare not,
For ſure I know a way to ſcape all dangers.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Madam, your lodgings lye this way.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: My Lodgings?
For heaven ſake ſir, what office doe I beare here?

sp.speaker: Ty.
sp.p: The great cōmander of all hearts Enter Leucippe, and Ladies.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You have hit it.
I thank your ſweet-heart for it. Who are theſe now?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Ladies that come to ſerve yee.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Well conſider'd,
Are you my ſervants?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Servants to your pleaſures.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I dare believe ye, but I dare not truſt ye:
Catch'd with a trick? well, I muſt beare it patiently:
Methinkes this Court's a neat place: all the people
Of ſuch refin'd a ſize—

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: This is no poore rogue.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Were it a Paradice to pleaſe your fancy,
And entertaine the ſweetneſſe you bring with ye;

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Take breath;
You are fat, and many words may melt ye,
This is three Bawdes beaten into one; bleſſe me heaven,
What ſhall become of me? I am i'th' pitfall:
O' my conſcience, this is the old viper, and all theſe little ones
Creep every night into her belly; do you heare plumpe ſervant
And you my litle ſucking Ladies, you muſt teach me,
For I know you are excellent at carriage,
How to behave my ſelfe, for I am rude yet:
But you ſay the Prince will come?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Will flie to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: For look you if a great man, ſay the King now
Should come and viſit me?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: She names ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Peace foole.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And offer me a kindneſſe, ſuch a kindneſſe.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I, ſuch a kindneſſe.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: True Lady ſuch a kindneſſe,
What ſhall that kindneſſe be now?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: A witty Lady,
Learne little ones, learne.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Say it be all his favour.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: And a ſweet ſaying 'tis.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And I grow peeviſh?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: You muſt not be neglectfull.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: There's the matter,
There's the maine doctrine now, and I may miſſe it.
Or a kind hanſome Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: You ſay well.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: They'l count us baſely bred.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Not freely nurtur'd.

sp.speaker: Cel
sp.l: I'le take thy counſell.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: 'Tis an excellent woman.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I find a notable volume here, a learnd one;
Which way? for I would faine be in my chamber;
In truth ſweet Ladies, I grow weary; fie,
How hot the aire beats on me?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: This way Madam?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Now by mine honour, I grow wondrous faint too.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Your fans ſweet Gentlewomen, your fans.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Since I am foold,
I'le make my ſelf ſome ſport, though I pay deare for't. Ex.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: You ſee now what a manner of woman ſhe is ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou art an aſſe.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Is this a fit love for the Prince?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A coxcombe:
Now by my crowne a deintie wench, a ſharpe wench,
And a matchleſſe ſpirit: how ſhe Jeer'd 'em?
How careleſly ſhe ſcoff'd 'em? uſe her nobly;
I would I had not ſeen her: waite anon,
And then you ſhall have more to trade upon. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: We muſt keep a round, and a ſtrong watch to night,
The Prince will not charge the Enemy till the morning:
But for the trick I told ye for this raſcall,
This rogue, that health and ſtrong heart makes a coward.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: I, if it take.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ne're feare it, the Prince has it,
And if he let it fall, I muſt not know it;
He will ſuſpect me preſently: but you two
May helpe the plough.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: That he is ſicke again.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Extreamely ſicke: his diſeaſe growne incurable,
Never yet found, nor touch'd at. Ent. Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Well, we have it
And here he comes.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: The Prince has been upon him,
What a flatten face he has now? it takes beleeve it;
How like an aſſe he lookes?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I feele no great paine,
At leaſt, I thinke I do not; yet I feele ſenſibly
I grow extreamely faint: how cold I ſweat now?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: So, ſo, ſo.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: And now 'tis ev'n too true, I feele a pricking,
A pricking, a ſtrange pricking: how it tingles?
And as it were a ſtitch too: the Prince told me,
And every one cri'd out I was a dead man;
I had thought I had been as well—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Upon him now boyes,
And do it moſt demurely.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: How now Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I thanke ye Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent
sp.l: Life, how lookes this man?
How doſt thou good Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: I ever told ye
This man was never cur'd, I ſee it too plaine now;
How do you feele your ſelfe? you looke not perfect,
How dull his eye hangs?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: That may be diſcontent.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Beleeve me friend, I would not ſuffer now
The tith of thoſe paines this man feeles; marke his forehead
What a cloud of cold dew hangs upon't?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I have it,
Againe I have it; how it growes upon me?
A miſerable man I am.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha,
A miſerable man thou ſhalt be,
This is the tameſt trout I ever tickell●.

sp.speaker: 1 Phis.
sp.l: This way he went. Enter 2 Phi.

sp.speaker: 2 Phis.
sp.l: Pray heaven we find him living,
He's a brave fellow, 'tis pitty he ſhould periſh thus.

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: A ſtrong hearted man, & of a notable ſufferance.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: How now? how is it man?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Oh Gentlemen,
Never ſo full of paine.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Did I not tell ye?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Never ſo full of paine Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: He is here;
How do you ſir?

sp.speaker: 2 Phi.
sp.l: Be of good comfort Souldier,
The Prince has ſent us to you.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Do you thinke I may live?

sp.speaker: 2 Phi.
sp.l: He alters hourely, ſtrangely.

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: Yes, you may live: but—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Finely butted Doctor.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Do not diſcourage him.

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: He muſt be told truth,
'Tis now too late to trifle. Enter Dem. and Gent.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Here the Prince comes.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: How now Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Be wailing ſir, a Souldier,
And one I thinke, your Grace will grieve to part with,
But every living thing—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: 'Tis true, muſt periſh,
Our lives are but our martches to our graves,
How doſt thou now Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Faith 'tis true ſir,
We are but ſpans, and candles ends.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He's finely mortified.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thou art heart whole yet; I ſee he alters ſtrangely,
And that a pace too; I ſaw it this morning in him,
When he poore man, I dare ſweare—

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: No beleev't ſir,
I never felt it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Heres lies the paine now: how he is ſwel'd?

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: The Impoſtume
Fed with a new malignant humour now,
Will grow to ſuch a bigneſſe, 'tis incredible,
The compaſſe of a buſhell will not hold it,
And with ſuch a hell of torture it will riſe too.—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Can you endure me touch it?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Oh, I beſeech you ſir:
I feele you ſenſibly ere you come neare me.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: He's finely wrought, he muſt be cut, no cure elſe,
And ſuddenlie, you ſee how faſt he blowes out.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Good Maſter Doctor, let me be beholding to you,
I feele I cannot laſt.

sp.speaker: 2 Phi.
sp.l: For what Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: But ev'n for halfe a dozen Cans of good wine,
That I may drinke my will out: I faint hideouſly.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Fetch him ſome wine; and ſince he muſt go gentlemen
Why let him take his journey merrily. Enter Servant with wine.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: That's ev'n the neareſt way.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I could laugh dead now.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Here, off with that.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Theſe two I give your Grace,
A poore remembrance of a dying man ſir,
And I beſeech you weare 'em out.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I will Souldier,
