Theſe are fine legacies.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Among the Gentlemen,
Even all I have left; I am a poore man, naked,
Yet ſomething for remembrance: foure a peece Gentlemen,
And ſo my body where you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: It will worke.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I make your Grace my executor, and I beſeech ye
See my poore will fulfill'd: ſure I ſhall walke elſe.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: As full as they can be ſill'd, here's my hand Souldier.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: The wine will tickle him.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I would heare a drum beat,
But to ſee how I could endure it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Beat a drum there. Drum within.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Oh heavenly muſick, I would heare one ſing to't,
I am very full of paine.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Sing? 'tis impoſible.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Why, then I would drinke a drum full:
Where lies the Enemie?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Why, here cloſe by.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Now he begins to muſter.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: And dare ye fight?
Dare ye fight Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: You muſt not cut him:
He's gone then in a moment; all the hope left, is
To worke his weakeneſſe into ſuddaine anger,
And make him raiſe his paſſion above his paine,
And ſo diſpoſe him on the enemie;
His body then, being ſtir'd with violence,
Will purge it ſelfe and breake the ſore.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: 'Tis true ſir.

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: And then my life for his.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I will not dye thus.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: But he is too weake to doe—

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Dye like a dog?

sp.speaker: 2 Phi.
sp.l: I, he's weake, but yet he's heart whole.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Hem.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: An excellent ſigne.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Hem.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Stronger ſtill, and better.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Hem, hem; tan, tan, tan, tan, tan. Exit.

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: Now he's i'th' way on't.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Well go thy waies, thou wilt do ſomething certain.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And ſome brave thing, or let mine eares be cut off.
He's finely wrought.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Let's after him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I pray Sir;
But how this rogue, when this cloud's melted in him,
And all diſcover'd. —

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: That's for an after mirth, away, away, away. Ex.

div.head: Scaene 6.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Let no man feare to dye: we love to ſleep all,
And death is but the ſounder ſleep; all ages,
And all houres call us; 'tis ſo common, eaſie,
That little children tread thoſe paths before us;
We are not ſicke, nor our ſoules preſt with ſorrows,
Nor go we out like tedious tales, forgotten;
High, high we come, and hearty to our funerals,
And as the Sun that ſets, in bloud let's fall.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: 'Tis true, they have us faſt, we cannot ſcape 'em,
Nor keeps the brow of fortune one ſmile for us,
Diſhonourable ends we can ſcape though,
And (worſe then thoſe, captivities) we can die,
And dying nobly, though we leave behind us
Theſe clods of fleſh, that are too maſſie burthens,
Our living ſoules flie crown'd with living conqueſts.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: They have begun, fight bravely, and fall bravely;
And may that man that ſeekes to ſave his life now
By price, or promiſe, or by feare fals from us, Enter a Souldier
Never again be bleſt with name of Souldier.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: How now? who charged firſt? I ſeek a brave hand
To ſet me off in death.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: We are not charg'd ſir,
The Prince lies ſtill.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: How comes this Latum up then?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: There is one deſperate fellow, with the devill in him
(He never durſt do this elſe) has broke into us,
And here he bangs ye two or three before him,
There five or ſixe; ventures upon whole companies.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: And is not ſeconded?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Not a man followes.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Nor cut a peeces?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Their wonder yet has ſtaid 'em.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Let's in, and ſee this miracle?

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: I admire it. Ex.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Fetch him off, fetch him off; I am ſure he's clouted;
Did I not 〈◊〉 you how 'twould take?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: 'Tis admirable.

div.stage: Enter Lieutenant with colours in his hand, purſuing 3 or 4 Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Follow that blow, my friend, there's at your coxcombs,
I fight to ſave me from the Surgeons miſeries.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How the knave curries 'em?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: You cannot rogues,
Till you have my diſeaſes, flie my furie,
Ye bread and butter rogues, do ye run from me?
And my ſide would give me leave, I would ſo hunt ye,
Ye porredge gutted ſlaves, ye veale-broth boobies.

div.stage: Enter Demetrius, and Phiſitians, and Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Enough, enough Lieutenant, thou haſt done bravely.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Mirrour of man.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: There's a flag for ye ſir,
I tooke it out o'th' ſhop, and never paid for't,
I'le to 'em againe, I am not come to th' text yet.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: No more my ſouldier: beſhrew my heart he is hurt ſore.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Hang him, hee'l lick all thoſe whole.

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: Now will we take him,
And cure him in a trice.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Be carefull of him.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Let me live but two yeares,
And doe what ye will with me;
I never had but two houres yet of happineſſe;
Pray ye give me nothing to provoke my valour,
For I am ev'n as weary of this fighting—

sp.speaker: 2 Phi.
sp.l: Ye ſhall have nothing; come to the Princes Tent
And there the Surgeons preſently ſhall ſearch ye,
Then to your reſt.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: A little hanſome litter
To lay me in, and I ſhall ſleepe.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Looke to him.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I do beleeve a horſe begot this fellow,
He never knew his ſtrength yet; they are our owne.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I thinke ſo, I am cozen'd elſe; I would but ſee now
A way to fetch theſe off, and ſave their honours.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Only their lives.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Pray ye take no way of peace now,
Unleſſe it be with infinite advantage.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I ſhall be rul'd;
Let the battels now move forward, Ent. Trumpet and Herold.
Our ſelfe will give the ſignall:
Now Herold, what's your meſſage?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: From my Maſters
This honourable courteſie, a Parley
For halfe an houre, no more ſir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Let 'em come on,
They have my princely word.

div.stage: Enter Seleucus, Lyſimacus, Ptolomy, attendants, Souldiers,

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: They are here to attend ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Now Princes, your demands?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Peace, if it may bee
Without the too much tainture of our honour:
Peace, and wee'l buy it too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: At what price?

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Tribute.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: At all the charge of this war.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: That will not do.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Leontius, you and I have ſerv'd together,
And run through many a fortune with our ſwords,
Brothers in wounds, and health; one meat has fed us,
One tent a thouſand times from cold night cover'd us:
Our loves have been but one; and had we died then,
One monument had held our names, and actions:
Why do you ſet upon your friends ſuch prizes?
And ſacrifice to giddy chance ſuch Trophies?
Have we forgot to dye? or are our vertues
Leſſe in afflictions conſtant, than our fortunes?
Ye are deceiv'd old ſouldier.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I know your worths,
And thus low bow in reverence to your vertues:
Were theſe my wars, or lead my power in chiefe here,
I knew then how to meet your memories:
They are my Kings imployments; this man fights now,
To whom I owe all dutie, faith, and ſervice;
This man that ſled before ye; call backe that,
That bloudy day againe, call that diſgrace home,
And then an eaſie peace, may ſheath our ſwords up.
I am not greedy of your lives and fortunes,
Nor do I gape ungratefully to ſwallow ye,
Honour the ſpur of all illuſtrious natures,
That made you famous Souldiers, and next Kings,
And not ambitious envy ſtrikes me forward,
Will ye unarme, and yeild your ſelves his priſoners?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: We never knew what that ſound meant: no gives
Shall ever bind this body, but embraces;
Nor weight of ſorrow here, till earth fall on me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Expect our charge then.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: 'Tis the nobler curteſie:
And ſo we leave the hand of heaven to bleſſe us.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Stay, have you any hope?

sp.speaker: Cel
sp.l: We have none left us,
But that one comfort of our deaths together;
Give us but room to ſight.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Win it, and weare it.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: Call from the hils thoſe companies hang ore us
Like burſting clouds; and then breake in, and take us.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Find ſuch a Souldier will forſake advantage,
And wee'l draw off, to ſhew I dare be noble,
And hang a light out to ye in this darkeneſſe,
The light of peace; give up thoſe Cities, forts,
And all thoſe frontire Countries to our uſes.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Is this the peace? traitours to thoſe that feed us,
Our Gods and people? give our Countries from us?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Begin the knell, it ſounds a great deale ſweeter.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: Let looſe your ſervant death.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Fall fate upon us,
Our memories ſhall never ſtinke behind us.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Seleucus, great Seleucus,

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: The Prince cals ſir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thou ſtocke of nobleneſſe, and curteſie,
Thou father of the war —

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What meanes the Prince now?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Give me my Standard here.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: His angers melted.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You Gentlemen that were his priſoners,
And felt the bounty of that noble nature,
Lay all your hands, and beare theſe Colours to him,
The Standard of the Kingdome; take it ſouldier.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: What will this meane?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thou haſt won it, beare it off,
And draw thy men home whilſt we waite upon thee.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: You ſhall have all our countries.

sp.speaker: Lyſ. Ptol.
sp.l: All by heaven ſir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I will not have a ſtone, a buſh, a bramble,
No, in the way of curteſie, I'le ſtart ye;
Draw off, and make a lane through all the Armie,
That theſe that have ſubdu'd us, may martch through us.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Sir, do not make me ſurfet with ſuch goodneſſe,
I'le beare your Srandard for ye; follow ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I ſweare it ſhall be ſo, martch through me fairely,
And thine be this daies honour, great Seleucus.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: Mirrour of noble minds.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Nay then ye hate me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I cannot ſpeake now: Ex with Drums, & Shouts.
Well, go thy wayes, at a ſure peece of bravery
Thou art the beſt, theſe men are won by th' neckes now:
I'le ſend a poſt away.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: NO aptneſſe in her?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Not an immodeſt motion,
And yet when ſhe is as free, and when ſhe is courted,
Makes as wild witty anſwers.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This more fires me,
I muſt not have her thus.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: We cannot alter her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Have ye put the youths upon her?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: All that know any thing,
And have been ſtudied how to catch a beauty,
But like ſo many whelps about an Elephant—
The Prince is coming home ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I heare that too,
But that's no matter; am I alter'd well;

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Not to be knowne I thinke ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I muſt ſee her. Ent. 2 Gent. or Lords.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: I offered all I had, all I could thinke of,
I tri'd her through all the points o'th' compaſſe, I thinke.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: She ſtudies to undo the Court, to plant here
The enemy to our age, chaſtitie;
She is the firſt, that ere bauked a cloſe Arbour,
And the ſweet contents within: She hates curl'd heads too,
And ſetting up or beards ſhe ſweares, is Idolatrie.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: I never knew ſo faire a face ſo froze;
Yet ſhe would make one thinke—

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: True by her carriage,
For ſhe's as wanton as a kid toth' out ſide,
As full of mocks and taunts: I kiſſ'd her hand too,
Walkt with her halfe an houre.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: She heard me ſing,
And ſung her ſelfe too; ſhe ſings admirably;
But ſtill, when any hope was, as 'tis her trick
To miniſter enough of thoſe, then preſently
With ſome new ſlam or other, nothing to th' matter,
And ſuch a frowne, as would ſinke all before her,
She takes her chamber; come we ſhal not be the laſt fools.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Not by a hundred I hope; 'tis a ſtrange wench.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This ſcrewes me up ſtill higher. Enter Celia, and Ladies behind her

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Here ſhe comes ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then be you gone: and take the women with ye,
And lay thoſe Jewels in her way.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: If I ſtay longer
I ſhall number as many lovers as Lais did;
How they ſlocke after me? upon my conſcience,
I have had a dozen horſes given me this morning,
I'le ev'n ſet up a troop, and turne ſhe-ſouldier.
A good diſcreet wench now, that were not hidebound
Might raiſe a fine eſtate here, and ſuddenly:
For theſe warme things will give their ſoules— I can go no where
Without a world of offerings to my excellence:
I am a Queene, a Goddeſſe, I know not what—
And no conſtellation in all heaven, but I outſhine it;
And they have found out now I have no eyes
Of mortall lights, but certaine influences,
Strange vertuous lightnings, humane nature ſtarts at,
And I can kill my twenty in a morning,
With as much caſe now—
Ha? what are theſe? new projects?
Where are my honourable Ladies? are you out too?
Nay then I muſt buy the ſtocke, ſend me good carding:
I hope the Princes hand, be not in this ſport;
I have not ſeen him yet, cannot heare from him,
And that, that, troubles me: all theſe were recreations
Had I but his ſweet companie to laugh with me:
What fellowes that? another apparition?
This is the lovingſt age: I ſhould know that face,
Sure I have ſeen't before, not long ſince neither.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She ſees me now: O heaven, a moſt rare creature!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Yes, 'tis the ſame: I will take no notice of ye,
But if I do not fit ye, let me frie for't;
Is all this Cackling for your eg? they are faire ones,
Excellent rich no doubt to; and may ſtumble
A good ſtaid mind, but I can go thus by 'em;
My honeſt friend; do you ſet off theſe Jewels?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Set 'em off, Lady?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I meane, ſell 'em here ſir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She's very quicke; for ſale they are not meant ſure.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: For ſanctitie I thinke much leſſe: good even Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay, noble Lady ſtay: 'tis you muſt weare 'em:
Never looke ſtrange, they are worthy your beſt beauty.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Did ye ſpeake to me?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To you or to none living:
To you they are ſent; to you they are ſacrificed.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I'le never looke a horſe i'th' mouth that's given:
I thanke ye ſir: I'le ſend one to reward ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do you never aske who ſent 'em?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Never I:
Nor never care, if it be an honeſt end,
That end's the full reward, and thankes but ſlubbers it;
If it be ill, I will not urge the acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This has a ſoule indeed: pray let me tell ye.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I care not if ye do, ſo you do it hanſomly,
And not ſtand picking of your words,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The King ſent 'em.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Away, away, thou art ſome fooliſh fellow,
And now I think thou haſt ſtole 'em too; the king ſent 'em?
Alas good man, wouldſt thou make me beleeve
He has nothing to do with things of theſe worths,
But wantonly to fling 'em? he's an old man,
A good old man, they ſay too: I dare ſweare
Full many a yeare ago, he left theſe gambols:
Here, take your trinkets.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sure I do not lye Lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I know thou lyeſt extreamely, damnably.
Thou haſt a lying face.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I was never thus ratled.

sp.speaker: Cel,
sp.l: But ſay I ſhould beleeve: why are theſe ſent me?
And why art thou the Meſſenger? who art thou?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Lady, looke on 'em wiſely, and then conſider
Who can ſend ſuch as theſe, but a King only?
And, to what beautie can they be oblations,
But only yours? For me that am the carrier,
'Tis only fit you know I am his ſervant,
And have fulfil'd his will.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You are ſhort and pitthy;
What muſt my beauty do for theſe?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sweet Lady,
You cannot be ſo hard of underſtanding,
When a Kings favour ſhines upon ye gloriouſly,
And ſpeakes his love in theſe,—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: O then love's the matter;
Sir-reverence love: now I begin to feele ye:
And I ſhould be the Kings whore, a brave title.
And go as glorious as the Sun, ô brave ſtill:
The chiefe Commandreſſe of his Concubines,
Hurried from place to place to meet his pleaſures.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A devilliſh ſubtill wench, but a rare ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And when the good old ſpunge had ſuckt my youth dry,
And left ſome of his royall aches in my bones:
When time ſhalt tell me I have plough'd my life up,
And caſt long furrowes in my face to ſinke me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You muſt not thinke ſo Lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Then can theſe ſir,
Theſe precious things, the price of youth and beauty;
This ſhop here of ſin-offerings ſet me off againe?
Can it reſtore me chaſte, young innocent?
Purge me to what I was? adde to my memorie
An honeſt and a noble fame? The Kings device;
The ſin's as univerſall as the Sun is,
And lights an everlaſting torch to ſhame me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Doe you hold ſo ſleight account of a great Kings favour,
That all knees bow to purchaſe?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Prethee peace:
If thou knewſt how ill-favouredly thy tale becomes thee,
And what ill root it takes—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You will be wiſer.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Could the King find no ſhape to ſhift his pander into,
But reverend age? and one ſo like himſelf too?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She has found me out.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Cozen the world with gravitie?
Prethee reſolve me one thing, do's the King love thee?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I thinke he doe's.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: It ſeemes ſo by thy office:
He loves thy uſe, and when thats ended, hates thee:
Thou ſeemeſt to me a ſouldier.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes I am one.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And haſt fought for thy Country?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Many a time.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: May be, commanded too?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have done, Lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: O wretched man, below the ſtate of pitie!
Canſt thou forget, thou wert begot in honour?
A free companion for a King? a ſouldier?
Whoſe nobleneſſe dare feele no want, but enemies?
Canſt thou forget this, and decline ſo wretchedly,
To eat the bread of bawdrie, of baſe bawdrie?
Feed on the ſcum of ſin? fling thy ſword from thee?
Diſhonour to the noble name that nurſed thee?
Goe, beg diſeaſes: let them be thy Armors,
Thy fights, the flames of luſt, and their foule iſſues.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why then I am a King, and mine owne ſpeaker.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And I as free as you, mine owne diſpoſer;
There take your jewels; let them give them luſtres
That have darke lives and ſoules; weare 'em your ſelfe ſir,
You'l ſeeme a Devill elſe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I command ye ſtay.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Be juſt, I am commanded.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I will not wrong ye.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Then thus low fals my duty.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Can ye love me?
Say I, and all I have.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I cannot love ye;
Without the breach of faith I cannot heare ye;
Ye hang upon my love, like froſts on Lillies:
I can dye, but I cannot love: you are anſwer'd. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I muſt find apter meanes, I love her truly. Exit.

div.head: Scaen. 2.
div.stage: Ent. Demetr. Leon. Lieut. Gent. Sold. & Hoſt.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Hether doe you ſay ſhe is come?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Yes ſir, I am ſure on't:
For whilſt I waited on ye, putting my wife in truſt,
I know not by what meanes, but the King found her,
And hether ſhe was brought; how, or to what end.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: My father found her?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: So my wife informes me.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Leontius, pray draw off the ſouldiers,
I would a while be private.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Fall off Gentlemen,
The Prince would be alone. Ex. Leo. & Sol.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Is he ſo cunning?
There is ſome tricke in this, and you muſt know it,
And be an agent too: which if it prove ſo —

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Pull me to pieces ſir?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: My father found her?
My father brought her hither? went ſhe willingly?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: My wife ſayes full of doubts.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I cannot blame her
No more: there's no truſt, no faith in mankinde.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Keep her up cloſe, he muſt not come to ſee her:
You are welcome nobly now, welcome home gentlemen;
You have done a courteous ſervice on the Enemie;
Has tyed his faith for ever; you ſhall find it;
Ye are not now in's debt Son: ſtill your ſad looks:
Leontius, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Truth ſir, I know not,
We have been merry ſince we went.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I feele it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come, what's the matter now? do you want money?
Sure he has heard o'th' wench.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Is that a want ſir?
I would faine ſpeake to your Grace.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You may doe freely.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And not deſerve your anger?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That ye may too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: There was a gentle woman, and ſomtimes my priſoner,
Which I thought well of ſir: your Grace conceives me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I doe indeed, and with much grief conceive ye;
With full as much griefe as your mother bare me:
There was ſuch a woman: would I might as well ſay,
There was no ſuch Demetrius.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: She was vertuous,
And therefore not unfit my youth to love her:
She was as faire —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Her beauty I'le proclaime too,
To be as rich as ever raigned in woman;
But how ſhe made that good, the Devill knowes.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: She was — O heaven!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The hell to all thy glories,
Swallowed thy youth, made ſhipwrack of thine honor:
She was a devill.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Ye are my father ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And ſince ye take a pride to ſhew your follies,
I'le muſter 'em, and all the world ſhall view 'em.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What heate is this? the Kings eyes ſpeak his anger?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou haſt abus'd thy youth; drawn to thy fellowſhip
In ſtead of arts and armes, a womans kiſſes,
The ſubtilties, and ſoft heates of a harlot.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Good ſir, miſtake her not.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A Witch, a Sorcerer:
I tell thee but the truth; and heare Demetrius,
Which has ſo dealt upon thy bloud with charmes,
Devilliſh and darke; ſo lockt up all thy vertues;
So pluckt thee backe from what thou ſprungſt from, glorious
In heaven, that any tongue but his durſt ſay this;
That any heart durſt harbor it: Dread Father,
If for the innocent the gods allow us
To bend our knees —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Away, thou art bewitched ſtill;
Though ſhe be dead, her power ſtill lives upon thee.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Dead? O ſacred ſir: dead did you ſay?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She is dead foole.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: It is not poſſible: be not ſo angry,
Say ſhe is falne under your ſad diſpleaſure,
Or any thing but dead, ſay ſhe is baniſhed,
Invent a crime, and doe beleeve it ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Dead by the Law: we found her hell, and her,
I meane her charmes and ſpels, for which ſhe periſh'd;
And ſhe confeſt ſhe drew thee to thy ruine,
And purpos'd it, purpos'd my Empires overthrow.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: But is ſhe dead? was there no pity ſir?
If her youth err'd, was there no mercy ſhewne her?
Did ye looke on her face, when ye condemn'd her?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I look'd into her heart, and there ſhe was hideous.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Can ſhe be dead? can vertue fall untimely?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She is dead, deſervingly ſhe died.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I have done then.
O matchleſſe ſweetnes, whether art thou vaniſhed?
O thou faire ſoule of all thy ſex, what Paradiſe
Haſt thou inrich'd and bleſt? I am your ſonne ſir,
And to all you ſhall command ſtand moſt obedient,
Only a little time I muſt intreat you
To ſtudy to forget her; 'twill not belong ſir,
Nor I long after it: art thou dead Celia,
Dead my poor wench? my joy, pluckt green with violence:
O faire ſweet floure, farwell: Come, thou deſtroyer,
Sorrow, thou melter of the ſoule, dwell with me;
Dwell with me ſolitarie thoughts, teares, cryings,
Nothing that loves the day, love me, or ſeeke me,
Nothing that loves his owne life haunt about me:
And Love, I charge thee, never charme mine eies more,
Nor ne're betray a beauty to my curſes:
For I ſhall curſe all now hate all, forſweare all,
And all the brood of fruitfull nature vex at,
For ſhe is gon that was all, and I nothing — Ex. & Gen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This opinion muſt be maintained.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: It ſhall be ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let him goe: I can at mine owne pleaſure
Draw him to'th' right againe: wait you inſtructions,
And ſee the ſouldier paid, Leontius:
Once more ye are welcome home all.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Health to your Majeſtie. — Exit Antig. &c.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thou wentſt along the journy, how canſt thou tell?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: I did, but I am ſure 'tis ſo: had I ſtaid behind,
I thinke this had not proved.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A wench the reaſon?

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.l: Who's that talks of a wench there?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: All this diſcontent
About a wench.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Where is this wench, good Colonell?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Prethee hold thy peace: who cals thee to counſell?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Why, if there be a wench —

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 'Tis fit thou know her: Enter 2 Gen.
That I'le ſay for thee, and as fit thou art for her,
Let her be mewed or ſtopt: how is it Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: 1. G.
sp.l: Hee's wondrous diſcontent, hee'l ſpeak to no man.

sp.speaker: 2. G.
sp.l: Has taken his chamber cloſe, admits no entrance;
Teares in his eyes, and cryings out.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: 'Tis ſo ſir,
And now I wiſh my ſelfe half hang'd ere I went this journey,

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What is this woman?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: I cannot tell ye,
But hanſome as heaven.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: She is not ſo high I hope ſir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Where is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I, that would be knowne.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Why ſirrah.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: I cannot ſhow ye neither;
The King has now diſpos'd of her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: There lyes the matter:
Will he admit none to come to comfort him?

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: Not any neare, nor let 'em knock their hearts out,
Will never ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: 'Tis the beſt way if he have her;
For look you, a man would be loath to be diſturb'd in's paſtime;
'Tis every good mans caſe.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 'Tis all thy living,
We muſt not ſuffer this, we dare not ſuffer it:
For when theſe tender ſoules meet deep afflictions,
They are not ſtrong enough to ſtruggle with 'em,
But drop away as ſnow does, from a mountaine,
And in the torrent of their owne ſighs ſinke themſelves:
I will, and muſt ſpeake to him.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: So muſt I too:
He promiſed me a charge.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Of what? of children
Upon my conſcience, thou haſt a double companie,
And all of thine owne begetting alreadie.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Thats all one,
I'le raiſe 'em to a Regiment, and there command 'em,
When they turne diſobedient, unbeget 'em:
Knock 'em o'th' head, and put in new.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A rare way;
But for all this, thou art not valiant enough
To dare to ſee the Prince now?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Do ye thinke he's angry?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Extreamely vext.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: to the endangering of any man comes neare him.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Yet, if thou couldſt but win him out,
VVhat ere thy ſuite were.
Beleeve it granted preſently.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Yet thou muſt thinke though,
That in the doing he may breake upon ye,
And —

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: If he do not kill me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: There's the queſtion.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: For halfe a dozen hurts?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Art thou ſo valiant?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Not abſolutely ſo neither: no it cannot be,
I want my impoſtumes, and my things about me,
Yet I'le make danger, Collonel.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 'Twill be rare ſport,
How ere it take; give me thy hand; if thou doſt this,
I'le raiſe thee up a horſe troope, take my word for't.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: What may be done by humane man?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Lets goe then.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.p: Away before the coole: he wil revenge els. Ex.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Will ſhe not yeeld?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: For all we can urge to her;
I ſwore I would marry her, ſhe laugh'd extremely,
And then ſhe rail'd like thunder.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Call in the Magitian. Enter Mag. with a bowle.
I muſt, and will obtaine her, I am aſhes elſe.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Are all the Philters in? charmes, powders, roots?
They are all in: and now I onely ſtay
The invocation of ſome helping ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To your worke then, and diſpatch.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Sit ſtill, and feare not.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I ſhall ne're indure theſe fights.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Away with the woman: goe wait without.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: When the Devils gone pray call me. Exit.
Be ſure you make it powerfull enough.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Pray doubt not.—He Conjures.
RIſe from the ſhades below,
All you that prove
The helpes of looſe Love;
Riſe and beſtow
Upon this Cup, what ever may compell
By powerfull Charme, and un-reſiſted Spell.
A heart un-warm'd to melt in Loves deſires,
Diſtill into this Liquor all your fires;
Heats, longings, teares,
But keepe back frozen feares,
That ſhe may know, that has all power defied,
Art is a power that will not be denied.
I Obey, I obey,
And am come to view e're day
Brought along, all may compell,
All the earth has, and one hell:
Here's a little little Flower.
This will make her ſweat an houre,
Then unto ſuch flames ariſe,
A thouſand joyes will not ſuffice.
Here's the powder of the Moone
With which ſhe caught Endymion,
The powerfull teares that Venus cryed,
When the Boy Adonis dyed.
Here's Medeas Charme, with which
Jaſons heart ſhe did bewitch,
Omphale this Spell put in
When ſhe made the Libian ſpin.
This dull root pluckt from Lethe ſtood,
Purges all pure thoughts, and good.
Theſe I ſtir thus, round, round, round,
Whilſt our light feet beat the ground.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Now ſir 'tis full, and whoſoever drinkes this
Shall violently doat upon your perſon,
And never ſleepe nor eate unſatisfied:
So many houres 'twill worke, and worke with violence,
And thoſe expired 'tis done. You have my art ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: See him rewarded liberally—Leucippe.
Here, take this bowle, and when ſhe calls for wine next—

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Be ſure you give her this, and ſee her drinke it;
Delay no time when ſhe calls next.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I ſhall ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let none elſe touch it on your life.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I am charged ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now if ſhe have an antidote art let her ſcape me.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: There's the door Lieutenant, if you dare do any thing.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Here's no man waites.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: H'as given a charge that none ſhall,
Nor none ſhall come within the hearing of him:
Dare ye goe forward?

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.l: Let me put on my skull firſt.
My head's almoſt beaten into th'pap of an Apple.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Are there no Guns i'th' doore?
The rogue will doe it,
And yet I know he has no ſtomack to't.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.l: What loope-holes are there when I knock for ſtones,
For thoſe may pepper me? I can perceeive none.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How he viewes the Fortification.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.l: Farewell Gentlemen,
If I be kill'd —

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Wee'le ſee thee buried bravely.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.l: Away: how ſhould I know that then? Ile knock ſoftly.
Pray heaven he ſpeak in a low voice now to comfort me:
I feele I have no heart to't: —Is't well, Gentlemen.
Colonel, my Troope—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A little louder.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.l: Stay, ſtay;
Here is a window, I will ſee, ſtand wide.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: By — he's charging of a Gun:
There's no ſuch matter.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.l: There's no body in this roome.
O'twas a fire-ſhovell:
Now ile knock lowder: if he ſay who's there,
As ſure he has ſo much manners, then will I anſwer him knock louder,
So finely & demurely: my Troop Colonel—

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Knock louder foole, he heares not.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.l: You foole, doe you.
Doe and ye dare now.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: I doe not undertake it.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.l: Then hold your peace, & medle with your own matters.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Now he will knock. Knocks louder.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.l: Sir, ſir: wil't pleaſe you heare ſir?
Your Grace: Ile looke againe: what's that?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He's there now.
Lord! How he ſtares! I ne're yet ſaw him thus alter'd:
Stand now, and take the Troope.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.l: Would I were in't,
And a good horſe under me: I muſt knock againe.
The devil's at my fingers ends: he comes now.
Now Colonel, if I live—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: The Troop's thine own Boy. Enter Dem. a piſtol.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: What deſperate foole, ambitious of his ruine?

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.l: Your father would deſire ye, ſit, to come to dinner.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thou art no more,

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.l: Now, now, now, now.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Poore coxcomb,
Why doe I aime at thee? Exit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: His feare has kill'd him. En. Leuc. with a bowl.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: I proteſt hee's almoſt ſtiffe: bend him, and rub him:
Hold his noſe cloſe, you, if you be a woman,
Helpe us a little: here's a man neere periſh't.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Alas, alas, I have nothing here about me.
Looke to my bowle: Ile run in preſently
And fetch ſome waters: bend him, and ſet him upwards.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A goodly man.— Exit.
Here's a brave heart: he's warme againe: you ſhall not

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Leave us i'th' lurch ſo, ſirrah.
Now he breathes too.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: If we had but any drinke to rayſe his ſpirits.
What's that i'th' bowle? upon my life good Liquor,
She would not owne it elſe.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: He ſees.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Looke up boy,
And take this cup, and drinke it off, I'le pledge thee,
Guide it to his mouth: he ſwallowes heartily.

sp.speaker: 2. Gen.
sp.l: Oh! feare and ſorrowes dry; 'tis off—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Stand up man.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Am I not ſhot?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Away with him, and cheere him:
Thou haſt won thy Troop.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I thinke I won it bravely.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Goe, I muſt ſee the Prince, he muſt not live thus;
And let me heare an houre hence from ye.
Well ſir — Ex. Gen. and Lieu.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Here, here: where's the ſicke Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Hee's up and gone, Lady.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Alas: that I came ſo late.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He muſt ſtill thanke ye,
Ye left that in a cup here did him comfort.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: That in the bowle?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Yes truly, very much comfort,
He dranke it off, and after it ſpoke luſtily.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Did he drinke it all?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: All off.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: The devill choke him,
I am undone: 'has twenty devils in him,
Undone for ever: left he none?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I thinke not.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: No not a drop: what ſhall become of me now?
Had he no where elſe to ſwound? a veng'ance ſwound him:
Undone, undone, undone: ſtay, I can lye yet,
And ſweare too at a pinch, thats all my comfort, Ent. De.
Look to him; I ſay look to him, & but mark what folows. Ex

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What a devill ayles the woman? here comes the Prince again,
With ſuch a ſadnes on his face, as ſorrow,
Sorrow her ſelf, but poorely imitates.
Sorrow of ſorrowes on that heart that caus'd it.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Why might ſhe not be falſe & treacherous to me?
And found ſo by my father? ſhe was a woman,
And many a one of that ſexe, young and faire,
As full of faith as ſhe have fallen, and fouly.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: It is a wench: O that I knew the circumſtance.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Why might not, to preſerve me from this ruine,
She having loſt her honor, and abuſed me,
My father chance the formes o'th' coines, and execute
His anger on a fault ſhe ne're committed,
Only to keep me ſafe? why ſhould I thinke ſo?
She never was to me but all obedience,
Sweetnes, and love.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How heartily he weeps now?
I have not wept theſe thirty yeares and upward;
But now, if I ſhould be hang'd I cannot hold from't;
It grieves me to the heart.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Who's that that mocks me?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A plague of him that mocks ye: I grieve truly,
Truly and heartily to ſee you thus ſir:
And if it lay in my power, Gods are my witneſſe,
Who ere he be, that tooke your ſweet peace from ye;
I am not ſo old yet, nor want I ſpirit—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: No more of that no more Leontius,
Revenges are the gods: our part is ſufferance:
Farewell, I ſhall not ſee thee long.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Good ſir, tell me the cauſe, I know there is a woman in't;
Doe you hold me faithfull? dare ye truſt your ſouldier?
Sweet Prince, the cauſe?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I muſt not, dare not tell it,
And as thou art an honeſt man, enquire not.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Will ye be merry then?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I am wondrous merry.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 'Tis wondrous well: you think now this becomes ye.
Shame on't, it does not ſir, it ſhewes not hanſomely;
If I were thus, you would ſweare I were an aſſe ſtraight;
A wooden aſſe; whine for a wench?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Prethee leave me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I will not leave ye for a ſit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: For that you may have any where for ſixepence,
And a deare pennyworth too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Nay, then you are troubleſome.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Not halfe ſo troubleſome as you are to your ſelf ſir;
Was that brave heart made to pant for a placket:
And now i'th' dog-daies too, when nothing dare love?
That noble mind to melt away, and moulder
For a hay-nonny-nonny? would I had a glaſſe here,
To ſhew ye what a pretty toy ye are turn'd to.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: My wretched fortune.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Will ye but let me know her?
I'le once turne bawd: go too, they are good mens offices,
And not ſo contemptible as we take 'em for:
And if ſhe be above ground, and a woman,
I aske no more; I'le bring her o' my backe ſir,
By this hand I will: and I had as lieve bring the devill,
I care not who ſhe be, nor where I have her,
And in your armes, or the next bed deliver her,
Which you thinke fitteſt: and when you have danc'd your galliard.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Away, and foole to them are ſo affected:
O thou art gone, and all my comfort with thee;
Wilt thou do one thing for me?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: All things i'th' world ſir,
Of all dangers.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Sweare.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Come neere me no more then.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Come no more neere me:
Thou art a plague-ſore to me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Give you good ev'n ſir;
If you be ſuffer'd thus, we ſhall have fine ſport.
I will be ſorry yet. Ent. 2 Gent.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: How now, how does he?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Nay, if I tell ye hang me, or any man elſe
That hath his nineteen wits; he has the bots I thinke,
He groanes, and roares, and kicks.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Will be ſpeake yet?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Not willingly:
Shortly he will not ſee a man; if ever
I look'd upon a Prince ſo metamorphis'd,
So juggled into I know not what, ſhame take me;
This 'tis to be in love.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Is that the cauſe on't?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What is it not the cauſe of but beare baitings?
And yet it ſtinkes much like it: out upon't,
What Giants, and what dwarffs, what owles and apes,
What dogs, and cats it makes us? men that are poſſeſt with it,
Live as if they had a legion of devils in 'em,
And every devill of a ſeverall nature,
Nothing but Hey paſſe, re-paſſe: where's the Lieutenant?
Has he gathered up the end on's wits againe?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: He is alive: but you that talke of wonders,
Shew me but ſuch a wonder as he is now.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Why? he was ever at the worſt a wonder.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: He is now moſt wonderfull; a blazer now ſir:

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What ailes the fooles? and what ſtar raignes now gentlemen
We have ſuch prodigies?

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: 'Twill poaze your heaven-hunters;
He talks now of the King, no other language,
And with the King, as he imagines hourely,
Courts the King, drinks to the King, dies for the King,
Buyes all the pictures of the King, wears the Kings colors,

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Does he not lye i'th' Kings ſtreet too?

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: Hee's going thither,
Makes praiers for the King in ſundry languages,
Turnes all his Proclamations into meeter,
Is really in love with the King, moſt doatingly,
And ſweares Adonis was a devill to him:
A ſweet King, a moſt comely King, and ſuch a King —

sp.speaker: 2. Gen.
sp.l: Then down on's mary-bones: O excellent King:
Thus he begins, Thou light and life of creatures,
Angell-ey'd King, vouchſafe at length thy favour;
And ſo proceeds to inciſion: what think ye of this ſorrow?

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: Will as familiarly kiſſe the Kings horſes
As they paſſe by him: ready to raviſh his footmen.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Why this is above Ela?
But how comes this?

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: Nay thats to underſtand yet,
But thus it is, and this part but the pooreſt,
'Twould make a man leap over the Moone to ſee him act theſe.

sp.speaker: 2. Gen.
sp.l: With ſighes as though his heart would breake:
Cry like a breech'd boy, not eat a bit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I muſt goe ſee him preſently,
For this is ſuch a gig: for certaine Gentlemen
The Fiend rides on a Fiddleſticke.

sp.speaker: 2. Gen.
sp.l: I thinke ſo.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Can ye guide me to him? for half an houre I am his,
To ſee the miracle.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: We ſure ſhall ſtart him. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Are you ſure ſhe dranke it?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Now muſt I lye moſt confidently.
Yes ſir, ſhe has drunke it off.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How works it with her?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I ſee no alteration yet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: There will be,
For he is the greateſt Artiſt living made it;
Where is ſhe now?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: She is ready to walke out ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Starke mad, I know ſhe will be.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: So I hope ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She knowes not of the Prince?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Of no man living—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How do I looke! how do my clothes become me?
I am not very gray.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: A very youth ſir,
Upon my maiden-head as ſmug as April:
Heaven bleſſe that ſweet face, 'twill undoe a thouſand,
Many a ſoft heart muſt ſob yet, ere that wither,
Your Grace can give content enough. Enter Celia with a book

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I thinke ſo.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Here ſhe comes ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How ſhall I keep her off me?
Go & perfume the room: make all things ready. Ex. Leu.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No hope yet of the Prince? no comfort of him?
They keep me mew'd up here, as they mew mad folkes,
No companie but my afflictions.
This royall devill againe? ſtrange, how he haunts me?
How like a poiſon'd potion his eyes fright me?
Has made himſelfe hanſome too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Doe you looke now, Lady?
You will leap anon.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Curl'd and perfum'd? I ſmell him:
He looks on's leggs too: ſure he will cut a caper,
God-a-mercie deare December.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O doe you ſmile now:
I knew it would worke with you: come hither pretty one.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I like thoſe curteſies well come hither & kiſſe me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I am reading ſir of a ſhort Treatiſe here,
Thats call'd the vanitie of luſt: has your Grace ſeene it?
He ſayes here, that an old mans looſe deſire
Is like the glow-wormes light, the Apes ſo wonder'd at:
Which when they gather'd ſticks, and laid upon't,
And blew, and blew, turn'd taile, and went out preſently:
And in another place, he cals their loves,
Faint ſmels of dying flowers, carry no comforts;
They'r doating ſtinking foggs, ſo thick and muddy,
Reaſon with all his beames cannot beat through 'em.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How's this? is this the potion? you but foole ſtill,
I know you love me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: As ye are juſt and honeſt,
I know I love and honour ye: admire ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This makes againſt me, fearfully againſt me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But as you bring your power to perſecute me,
Your traps to catch mine innocence, to rob me,
As you lay out your luſts to overwhelme me,
Hell never hated good, as I hate you ſir;
And I dare tell it to your face: What glory
Now after all your Conqueſts got, your Titles,
The ever-living memories raſs'd to you.
Can my defeat be? my poore wracke, what triumph?
And when you crowne your ſwelling cups to fortune,
What honourable tongue can ſing my ſtory?
Be as your Embleme is, a glorious Lamp
Set on the top of all, to light all perfectly:
Be as your office is, a god like Juſtice,
Into all ſhedding equally your vertues.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She has drencht me now: now I admire hir goodnes;
So young, ſo nobly ſtrong, I never taſted:
Can nothing in the power of Kings perſwade ye?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No, nor that power command me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Say I ſhould force ye?
I have it in my will.

sp.speaker: Cel
sp.l: Your will's a poore one;
And though it be a Kings will, a deſpiſed one,
Weaker then Infants leggs, your will's in ſwadling clouts:
A thouſand waies my will has found to checke ye;
A thouſand doores to leape ye I dare die ſir
As ſuddenly I dare die, as you can offer:
Nay, ſay you had your will, ſay you had raviſh'd me,
Perform'd your luſt, what had you purchas'd by it?
What honor won, doe you know who dwels above ſir,
And what they have prepared for men turn'd devils?
Did you never heare their thunder? ſtart and tremble,
Death ſitting on your bloud, when their fires viſit us?
Will nothing wring you then do you thinke? ſit hard here?
And like a ſnaile curle round about your conſcience
Biting and ſtinging: will you not roare too late then?
Then when you ſhake in horror of this villanie,
Then will I riſe a ſtar in heaven, and ſcorne ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Luſt, how I hate thee now? and love this ſweetneſſe?
Will ye be my Queene? can that price purchaſe ye?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Not all the world, I am a Queene alreadie;
Crown'd by his love, I muſt not loſe for fortune;
I can give none away, ſell none away ſir,
Can lend no love, am not mine owne Exchequer;
For in anothers heart my hope and peace lyes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Your faire hands, Lady: for yet I am not pure enough
To touch theſe lips, in that ſweet peace ye ſpoke of:
Live now for ever, and I to ſerve your vertues —

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Why now ye ſhow a god? now I kneele to ye;
This ſacrifice of Virgins joy ſend to ye:
Thus I hold up my hands to heaven that touch'd ye,
And pray eternall bleſſings dwell about ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Vertue commands the ſtars: riſe more then vertue;
Your preſent comfort ſhall be now my buſines.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: All my obedient ſervice wait upon ye. Ex. ſeverally.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Haſt thou cleane forgot the wars?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Prethee hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: His mind's much elevated now.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: It ſerves ſo
Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I am ſo troubled with this fellow.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He will call me rogue anon.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: Tis ten to one elſe.

sp.speaker: Lie.
sp.l: O King, that thou knew'ſt I loved thee, how I lov'd thee:
And where O King I barrell up thy beauty.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He cannot leave his Sutlers trade, he wooes in't.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: O never King.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: By this hand, when I conſider —

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: My honeſt friend, you are a little ſawcy.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: I told you you would have it.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: When mine owne worth —

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Is flung into the ballance, and found nothing.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: And yet a ſouldier.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And yet a ſawcy one.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: One that has followed thee.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Faire and far off.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Fought for thy grace.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 'Twas for ſome griefe, you lye Sir.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Hee's the ſon of a whore denies this: will that ſatisfie ye?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Yes, very well.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Shall then that thing that honors thee?
How miſerable a thing ſoever, yet a thing ſtill;
And though a thing of nothing, thy thing ever.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Heere's a new thing.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: Hee's in a deep dump now.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: I'le fetch him out on't. When's the Kings birth-day

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: When ere it be, that day I'le dye with ringing,
And there's the reſolution of a Lover. Exit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A goodly reſolution ſure I take it,
He is bewitch'd, or moop'd, or his braines melted,
Could he find no body to fall in love with; but the King,
The good old King, to doat upon him too?
Stay, now I remember what the fat woman warn'd me,
Bad me remember and look to him too:
Ile hang if ſhe have not a hand in this: hee's conjured,
Goe after him. I pitty the poore raſcall,
In the meane time Ile wait occaſion
To worke upon the Prince.

sp.speaker: 2. Gen.
sp.l: Pray doe that ſeriouſly. Ex. ſeverally.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Hee's very ill.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am very ſorry for't,
And much aſhamed I have wronged his innocence,
Menippus, guide her to the Princes lodgings,
There leave her to his love againe.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I am glad ſir.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: He will ſpeake to none.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O I ſhall breake that ſilence;
Be quicke, take faire attendance.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Yes ſir preſently. Ex.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He will find his tongue, I warrant ye; his health too;
I ſend a phiſick will not faile.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Faire worke it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: We heare the Princes meane to viſit us
In way of truce.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Tis thought ſo.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come: lets in then,
And think upon the nobleſt wayes to meet 'em. Ex.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: There's no way now to get in: all the lights ſtopt too;
Nor can I heare a ſound of him: pray heaven
He uſe no violence: I thinke he has more ſoule
Stronger, and I hope nobler: would I could but ſee once
This beauty he groanes under, or come to know
But any circumſtance. What noiſe is that there?
I thinke I heard him groane: here are ſome comming;
A woman too, Ile ſtand aloof, and view 'em.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Well, ſome of ye have been too blame in this point,
But I forgive ye: The King might have pickt out too
Some fitter woman to have tride his valour.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Twas all to the beſt meant, Lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I muſt thinke ſo,
For how to mend it now: hee's here you tell me?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Hee's Madam, and the joy to ſee you only
Will draw him out.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I know that womans tongue,
I thinke I have ſeene her face too: Ile goe nearer:
If this be ſhe, he has ſome cauſe of ſorrow:
'Tis the ſame face; the ſame, moſt excellent woman.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: This ſhould be Lord Leontius: I remember him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Lady, I thinke ye know me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Speake ſoft, good ſouldier:
I do, and know ye worthy, know ye noble;
Know not me yet openly, as you love me;
But let me ſee ye againe, Ile ſatisfie ye:
I am wondrous glad to ſee thoſe eyes.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You have charged me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You ſhall know where I am.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I will not off yet:
She goes to knocke at's doore: This muſt be ſhe
The fellow told me of: right glad I am on't,
He will bolt now for certaine.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Are ye within ſir?
Ile trouble you no more: I thanke your curteſie,
Pray leave me now.

sp.speaker: All. Me.
sp.p: We reſt your humble ſervants. Ex. Men. &c.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: So now my gyves are off: pray heaven he be here!
Maſter, my royall ſir: doe you heare who cals ye?
Love my Demetrius.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Theſe are pretty quaile-pipes,
The Corke will come anon.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Can ye be drowſie,
When I call at your window?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I heare him ſtirring: Enter Demetrius.
Now he comes wondring out.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Tis Gelias ſound ſure:
The ſweetneſſe of that tongue drawes all hearts to it;
There ſtands the ſhape too.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: How he ſtares upon her?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Ha? do mine eyes abuſe me?
'Tis ſhe, the living Celia: your hand Lady?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What ſhould this meane?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: The very ſelfe ſame Celia.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How do ye ſir?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Only turn'd brave.
I heard you were dead my deare on: compleat,
She is wondrous brave, a wondrous gallant Courtier.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How he ſurveies me round? here has been foule play.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: How came ſhe thus?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: It was a kind of death ſir,
I ſuffered in your abſence, meu'd up here,
And kept conceal'd I know not how.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: 'Tis likely:
How came you hether Celia? wondrous gallant:
Did my father ſend for ye?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: So they told me Sir,
And one command too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I hope you were obedient?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I was ſo ever.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And ye were bravely us'd?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I wanted nothing:
My maiden-head to a more i'th' Sun, he's jealous:
I muſt now play the knave with him, to dye for't,
'Tis in me nature.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Her very eyes are alter'd:
Jewels, and rich ones too, I never ſaw yet—
And what were thoſe came for ye?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Monſtrous jealous:
Have I liv'd at the rate of theſe ſcorn'd queſtions?
They ſeemed of good ſort Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Kind men?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: They were wondrous kind:
I was much beholding to 'em;
There was one Menippus ſir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: One Menippus,
A notable merry Lord, and a good companion.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And one Charinthus too?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Yes, there was ſuch a one.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And Timon?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis moſt true.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And thou moſt treacherous:
My fathers bawdes by—they never miſſe courſe;
And were theſe daily with ye?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Every houre ſir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And was there not a Lady, a fat Lady?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: O Yes; a notable good wench:

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: The devill fetch her.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis ev'n the merrieſt wench—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Did ſhe keepe with ye too?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: She was all in all; my bedfellow, eate with me,
Brought me acquainted.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You are well knowne here then?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: There is no living here a ſtranger I thinke.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: How came ye by this brave gowne?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: This is a poore one:
Alas, I have twenty richer: do you ſee theſe jewels?
Why, they are the pooreſt things, to thoſe are ſent me,
And ſent me hourely too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Is there no modeſtie?
No faith in this faire Sexe?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What will this prove too?
For yet with all my wits, I underſtand not.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Come hether; thou art dead indeed, loſt, tainted;
All that I left thee faire, and innocent,
Sweet as thy youth, and carrying comfort in't;
All that I hoped for vertuous, is fled from thee,
Turnd' backe, and banckrupt.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: By'r Lady, this cuts ſhrewdly.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thou art dead, for ever dead; ſins ſurfet ſlew thee;
The ambition of thoſe wanton eyes betraid thee;
Go from me grave of honor; go thou foule one,
Thou glory of thy ſin; go thou diſpis'd one,
And where there is no vertue, nor no virgin;
Where Chaſtitie was never knowne, nor heard of;
Where nothing reigns but imperious luſt, and loſers faces
Goe thether, child of bloud, and ſing my doating.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You do not ſpeake this ſeriouſly I hope ſir;
I did but jeſt with you.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Looke not upon me,
There is more hell in thoſe eyes, then hell harbours;
And when they flame, more torments.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Dare ye truſt me?
You durſt once even with all you had: you love ſir?
By this faire light I am honeſt.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thou ſubtle Circes,
Caſt not upon the maiden light eclipſes:
Curſe not the day.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Come, come, you ſhall not do this:
How faine you would ſeeme angry now, to fright me;
You are not in the field among your enemies;
Come, I muſt coole this courage.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Out thou impudence,
Thou ulcer of thy Sexe; when I firſt ſaw thee,
I drew into mine eyes mine owne deſtruction,
I puld into my heart that ſudden poyſon,
That now conſumes my deare content to ſinders:
I am not now Demetrius, thou haſt chang'd me;
Thou woman with thy thouſand wiles haſt chang'd me;
Thou Serpent with thy angell-eyes haſt ſlaine me;
And where, before I touch'd on this faire ruine,
I was a man, and reaſon made, and mov'd me,
Now one great lump of griefe. I grow and wander.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And as you are noble, do you thinke I did this?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Put all the devills wings on, and flie from me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I will go from ye, never more to ſee ye:
I will flie from ye, as a plague hangs o're me;
And through the progreſſe of my life hereafter;
Where ever I ſhall find a foole, a falſe man,
One that ne're knew the worth of polliſh'd vertue;
A baſe ſuſpecter of a virgins honour,
A child that flings away the wealth he cride for,
Him will I call Demetrius: that foole Demetrius,
That mad man a Demetrius; and that falſe man,
The Prince of broken faiths, even Prince Demetrius.
You thinke now, I ſhould cry, and kneele down to ye,
Petition for my peace; let thoſe that feele here
The weight of evill, waite for ſuch a favour,
I am above your hate, as far above it,
In all the actions of an innocent life,
As the pure Stars are from the muddy meators:
Crye when you know you folly: howle and curſe then,
Beate that unmanly breaſt, that holds a falſe heart
When ye ſhall come to know, whom ye have flung from ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Pray ye ſtay a little.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Not your hopes can alter me,
Then let a thouſand backe thoughts muſter in ye,
And with thoſe enter in a thouſand doatings;
Thoſe eyes be never ſhut, but drop to nothing:
My innocence for ever haunt and fright ye:
Thoſe armes together grow in folds; that tongue,
That bold bad tongue that barkes out theſe diſgraces.
When you ſhall come to know how nobly vertuous
I have preſerv'd my life, rot, rot within ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: What ſhall I doe?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Live a loſt man for ever.
Goe aske your fathers conſcience what I ſuffered,
And through what ſeas of hazards I ſayl'd through:
Mine honour ſtill advanced in ſpight of tempeſts,
Then take your leave of love; and confeſſe freely,
You were never worthy of this heart that ſerv'd ye,
And ſo farewell ungratefull— Exit.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Is ſhe gone?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Ile follow her, and will find out this matter. - Exit.

sp.speaker: Antig.
sp.l: Are ye pleas'd now? have you got your heart again?
Have I reſtor'd ye that?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Sir: even for heavens ſake,
And ſacred truth ſake, tell me how ye found her.

sp.speaker: Antig.
sp.l: I will, and in few words. Before I tride her,
'Tis true, I thought her moſt unfit your fellowſhip,
And fear'd her too: which feare begot that ſtory
I told ye firſt: but ſince, like gold I toucht her.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And how deare ſir?

sp.speaker: Antig.
sp.l: Heavens holy light's not purer:
The conſtancy and goodneſſe of all women
That ever liv'd, to win the names of worthy,
This noble Maid has doubled in her: honour,
All promiſes of wealth, all art to win her,
And by all tongues imploy'd, wrought as much on her
As one may doe upon the Sun at noone day
By lighting Candles up: her ſhape is heavenly,
And to that heavenly ſhape her thoughts are angells.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Why did you tell me ſir?

sp.speaker: Antig.
sp.l: 'Tis true, I err'd in't:
But ſince I made a full proofe of her vertue,
I find a King too poore a ſervant for her.
Love her, and honour her; in all obſerve her.
She muſt be ſomething more then time yet tels her:
And certaine I beleeve him bleſt, enjoyes her:
I would not loſe the hope of ſuch a daughter,
To adde another Empire to my honour. — Exit.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: O wretched ſtate! to what end ſhall I turn me?
And where begins my penance? now, what ſervice
Will win her love againe? my death muſt doe it:
And if that ſacrifice can purge my follies,
Be pleas'd, O mightie Love, I dye thy ſervant— Exit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I Know he do's not deſerve ye; h'as us'd ye poorely:
And to redeeme himſelfe—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Redeeme?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I know it—
There's no way left:

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: For heavens ſake doe not name him.
Doe not thinke on him ſir, he's ſo far from me
In all my thoughts now, methinkes I never knew him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: But yet I would ſee him againe.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No, never, never.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I doe not meane to lend him any comfort;
But to afflict: him, ſo to torture him;
That even his very ſoule may ſhake within him:
To make him know, though he be great and powerfull,
'Tis not within his aime to deale diſhonourably,
And carry it off, and with a maid of your ſort.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I moſt confeſſe, I could moſt ſpightfully afflict him;
Now, now, I could whet my anger at him;
Now, arm'd with bitterneſſe, I could ſhoot through him;
I long to vex him:

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And doe it home, and bravely:

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Were I a man?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ile helpe that weakeneſſe in ye:
I honour ye, and ſerve ye.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Not onely to diſclaime me,
When he had ſeal'd his vowes in heaven, ſworne to me,
And poore beleeving I became his ſervant:
But moſt maliciouſly to brand my credit,
Staine my pure name.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I would not ſuffer it:
See him I would againe, and to his teeth too:
Od's precious, I would ring him ſuch a leſſon—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I have done that already.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Nothing, nothing:
It was too poore a purge; beſides, by this time
He has found his fault, and feeles the hells that follow it.
That, and your urg'd on anger to the higheſt.
Why, 'twill be ſuch a ſtroake—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Say he repent then,
And ſeeke with teares to ſoften, I am a woman;
A woman that have lov'd him, ſir, have honour'd him:
I am no more.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Why, you may deale thereafter.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: If I forgive him, I am loſt.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Hold there then,
The ſport will be to what a poore ſubmiſſion —
But keepe you ſtrong.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I would not ſee him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Yes,
You ſhall ring his knell:

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How if I kill him?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Kill him: why, let him dye.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I know 'tis fit ſo.
But why ſhould I that lov'd him once, deſtroy him?
O had he ſcap't this ſin, what a brave Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I muſt confeſſe, had this not falne, a nobler,
A handſomer, the whole world had not ſhow'd ye:
And to his making ſuch a mind.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis certaine:
But all this I muſt now forget.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You ſhall not
If I have any art: goe up ſweet Lady,
And truſt my truth.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But good ſir bring him not.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I would not for the honour ye are born too,
But you ſhall ſee him, and neglect him too, and ſcorn him.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You will be neere me then.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I will be with ye;
Yet ther's ſome hope to ſtop this gap, ile work hard. Exe.

div.head: Scaene 2.
div.stage: Enter Antigonus, Menippus, two Gent. Lieutenant, and Lords.

sp.speaker: Antig.
sp.l: But is it poſſible this fellow tooke it?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: It ſeemes ſo by the violence it wrougkt with,
Yet now the fits ev'n off.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I beſeech your Grace.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay, I forgive thy wife with all my heart,
And am right glad ſhe dranke it not her ſelfe,
And more glad that the vertuous maid eſcapt it,
I would not for the world 'thad hit: but that this Souldier,
Lord how he lookes, that he ſhould take this vomit;
Can he make rimes too?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: 'Has made a thouſand ſir,
And plaies the burthen to 'em on a Jewes-trump.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He lookes as though he were bepiſt: do you love me ſir?

sp.speaker: Lie.
sp.l: Yes ſurely even with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I thanke ye;
I am glad I have ſo good a ſubject: but pray ye tell me,
How much did ye love me, before ye dranke this matter?

sp.speaker: Lie.
sp.l: Even as much as a ſober man might; & a Souldier
That your Grace owes juſt halfe a yeares pay to.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well remembred;
And did I ſeeme ſo young and amiable to ye?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Methought you were the ſweeteſt youth —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That's excellent.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I truly ſir; and ever as I thought on ye,
I wiſh'd, and wiſh'd—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What didſt thou wiſh I prethee?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Ev'n, that I had been a wench of fifteene for ye,
A hanſome wench ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why? God a mercy Souldier:
I ſeeme not ſo now to thee.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Not all out:
And yet I have a grudging to your Grace ſtill.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou waſt never in love before?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Not with a King,
And hope I ſhall never be again: Truly ſir,
I have had ſuch plundges, and ſuch bickrings,
And as it were ſuch runnings atilt within me,
For whatſoever it was provok't me toward ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: God-a-mercy ſtill.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I had it with a vengeance,
It plaid his prize.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I would not have been a wench then,
Though of this age.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: No ſure, I ſhould have ſpoiled ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well, goe thy waies, of all the luſty lovers
That ere I ſaw — wilt have an other potion?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: If you will be another thing, have at ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha: give me thy hand, from henceforth thou art my ſouldier,
Do bravely, Ile love thee as much.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I thanke ye;
But if you were mine enemie, I would not wiſh it ye:
I beſeech your Grace, pay me my charge.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: Thats certaine ſir;
Has bought up all that ere he found was like ye,
Or any thing you have lov'd, that he could purchaſe;
Old horſes, that your Grace has ridden blind, & foundee'd;
Dogs, roſten hawkes, and which is more then all this,
Has worne your Graces Gauntlet in his Bonnet.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Bring in your Bils: mine own love ſhall be ſatisfi'd;
And ſirrah, for this potion you have taken,
Ile point ye out a portion ye ſhall live on.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Twas the beſt draught that ere ye drunk.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I hope ſo.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Are the Princes come to'th' Court?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: They are all, and lodg'd ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come then, make ready for their entertainment,
Which preſently wee'l give: wait you on me ſir.

sp.speaker: Lie.
sp.l: I ſhal love drinke the better whilſt I live boyes. Ex.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Let me but ſee her deare Leontius;
Let me but dye before her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Would that would doe it:
If I knew where ſhe lay now, with what honeſtie,
You having flung ſo maine a miſchiefe on her,
And on ſo innocent and ſweet a Beautie,
Dare I preſent your viſit?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Ile repent all:
And with the greateſt ſacrifice of ſorrow
That ever Lover made.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Twill be too late ſir:
I know not what will become of you.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You can help me.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: It may be to her ſight: what are you nearer;
She has ſworne ſhe will not ſpeake to ye, looke upon ye,
And to love ye againe, O ſhe cries out, and thunders,
She had rather love — there is no hope —

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Yes Leontius,
There is a hope, which though it draw no love to it,
At leaſt will draw her to lament my fortune,
And that hope ſhall relieve me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Harke ye ſir, harke ye:
Say I ſhould bring ye —

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Do not trifle with me?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I will not trifle; both together bring ye,
You know the wrongs ye' done.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I do confeſſe 'em.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And if you ſhould then jump into your fury,
And have another querke in your head.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I'le dye firſt.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You muſt ſay nothing to her; for 'tis certaine,
The nature of your crime will admit no excuſe.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I will not ſpeake, mine eyes ſhall tell my penance.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You muſt looke wondrous ſad too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I need not looke ſo,
I am truly ſadneſſe ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: That looke will do it:
Stay here, I'le bring her to you inſtantly:
But take heed how you beare your ſelfe: ſit down there,
The more humble you are, the more ſhe'l take compaſſion
Women are per'lous things to deale upon. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: What ſhall become of me? to curſe my fortune,
Were but to curſe my father; that's too impious;
But under whatſoever fate I ſuffer,
Bleſſe I beſeech thee heaven her harmleſſe goodneſſe.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Now arme your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You have not brought him?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Yes faith,
And there he is: you ſee in what poore plight too,
Now you may doe your will, kill him, or ſave him.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I will goe back.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I will be hang'd then Lady,
Are yee a coward now?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I cannot ſpeak to him.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: O me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: There was a ſigh to blow a Church downe;
So, now their eyes are fixt, the ſmall ſhot playes,
They will come toth' batterie anon.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: He weeps extreamly.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Raile at him now.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I dare not.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I am glad on't.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Nor dare beleeve his teares.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You may bleſt beauty,
For thoſe thicke ſtreames that troubled my repentance,
Are crept out long agoe.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You ſee how he looks.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What have I to doe how he looks? how lookt he then,
When with a poiſoned truth he bit mine honour,
It was your counſell too, to ſcorne and ſlight him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I, if ye ſaw fit cauſe; and you confeſt too,
Except this ſin, he was the braveſt gentleman,
The ſweeteſt, nobleſt: I take nothing from ye,
Nor from your anger; uſe him as you pleaſe:
For to ſay truth, he had deſerved your juſtice;
But ſtill conſider what he has been to you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Pray doe not blinde me thus.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: O gentle Miſtris,
If there were any way to expiate
A ſinne ſo great as mine, by interceſſion,
By praiers, by daily teares, by dying for ye:
O what a joy would cloſe theſe eyes that love ye.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: They ſay women have tender hearts, I know not,
I am ſure mine melts.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sir, I forgive ye heartily,
And all your wrong to me I caſt behind me,
And wiſh ye a fit beauty to your vertues:
Mine is too poore, in peace I part thus from you;
I muſt look back: gods keep your Grace: he's here ſtill. Ex.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: She has forgiven me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: She has directed ye:
Up, up, and follow like a man: away ſir,
She lookt behind her twice: her heart dwels here ſir,
Ye drew teares from her too: ſhe cannot freeze thus;
The doore's ſet open too, are ye a man?
Are ye alive? doe ye underſtand her meaning?
Have ye bloud and ſpirit in ye?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I dare not trouble her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Nay, and you will be nipt i'th' head with nothing,
Walke whining up and downe; I dare not, I cannot:
Strike now or never: faint heart, you know what ſir—
Be govern'd by your feare, and quench your fire out.
A devill on't ſtands this doore ope for nothing:
So get ye together, and be naught: now to ſecure all,
Will I go fetch out a more ſoveraigne plaiſter. Ex.

div.head: Scaene 4.
div.stage: Enter Antigonus, Seleucus, Lyſimachus, Ptolomey, Lieuten. Gent. Lords.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This peace is fairely made.

sp.speaker: Seleu.
sp.l: Would your Grace wiſh us
To put in more: take what you pleaſe, we yeeld it;
The honour done us by your ſonne conſtraines it,
Your noble ſonne.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It is ſufficient, Princes;
And now we are one againe, one mind, one body,
And one ſword ſhall ſtrike for us.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Let Prince Demetrius
But lead us on: for we are his vowed ſervants;
Againſt the ſtrength of all the world wee'l buckle.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: And even from all that ſtrength wee'l catch at victory.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: O had I now recover'd but the fortune
I loſt in Antioch, when mine Unckle periſh'd;
But that were but to ſurfeit me with bleſſings.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: You loſt a ſweet childe there.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Name it no more ſir;
This is no time to entertaine ſuch ſorrowes;
Wil your Majeſtie do us the honor, we may ſee the Prince,
And wait upon him? Enter Leon.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I wonder he ſtayes from us:
How now Leontius, where's my ſonne?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Brave Captaine.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Old valiant ſir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Your Graces are welcome:
Your ſonne and't pleaſe you ſir, is new caſheered yonder,
Caſt from his Miſtris favour: and ſuch a coile there is;
Such fending, and ſuch proving; ſhe ſtands off,
And will by no meanes yeeld to compoſition:
He offers any price; his body to her.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: She is a hard Lady, denies that caution.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And now they whine, & now they rave: faith Princes,
'Twere a good point of charitie to piece 'em;
For leſſe then ſuch a power will doe juſt nothing:
And if you meane to ſee him, there it muſt be,
For there will he grow, till he be tranſplanted.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Beſeech your Grace, lets wait upon you thither,
That I may ſee that beauty dares deny him,
That ſcornfull beautie.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: I ſhould thinke it worſe now;
Ill brought up beautie.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She has too much reaſon for't;
Which with too great a grief, I ſhame to thinke of,
But wee'l goe ſee this game.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Rather this wonder.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Be you our guide Leontius, here's a new peace. Ex.

div.head: Scaene 5.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Thus far you ſhall perſwade me ſtill to honour ye,
Still to live with ye ſir, or neere about ye;
For not to lye, you have my firſt and laſt love,
But ſince you have conceiv'd an evill againſt me,
An evill that ſo much concernes your honour,
That honour aim'd by all at for a patterne:
And though there be a falſe thought, and confeſt too,
And much repentance falne in ſhoures to purge it;
Yet, whilſt that great reſpect I ever bore ye,
Dwels in my bloud, and in my heart that duty;
Had it but been a dreame, I muſt not touch ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: O you will make ſome other happy?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Never,
Upon this Hand I'le ſeale that faith.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: We may kiſſe,
Put not thoſe out o'th' peace too.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Thoſe I'le give ye,
So there you will be pleas'd to pitch your ultra,
I will be merry with ye; ſing, diſcourſe with ye,
Be your poore Miſtris ſtill: in truth I love ye.

div.stage: Enter Leontius, Antigonus, Seleucus, Lyſimachus, Ptolomy, Lieutenant, Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Stay, who are theſe?

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: A very hanſome Lady?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: As ere you ſaw.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Pitty her heart's ſo cruell.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: How does your Grace? he ſtands ſtill, will not heare us.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: We come to ſerve ye ſir, in all our fortunes.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: He bowes a little now; he's ſtrangely alter'd.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Ha? pray ye a word Leontius, pray ye a word with ye
Lyſimachus? you both knew mine Enanthe,
I loſt in Antioch, when the Towne was taken,
Mine unckle ſlaine, Antigonus had the ſack on't?

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Yes, I remember well the girle.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Methinkes now
That face is wondrous like her: I have her Picture,
The ſame, but more yeares on her; the very ſame.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: A cherry to a cherry is not liker.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Looke on her eyes.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Moſt certaine ſhe is like her:
Many a time have I dandled her in theſe armes ſir,
And I hope who will more.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What's that ye looke at, Princes?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: This picture, and that Lady ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ha: they are neare:
They only erre in time.

sp.speaker: Lyſ.
sp.l: Did you marke that bluſh there?
That came the neareſt.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I muſt ſpeake to her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You'l quickly be reſolved.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Your name ſweet Lady?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Enanthe, ſir: and this to beg your bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Doe you know me?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: If you be the King Seleucus,
I know you are my father.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Peace a little,
Where did I loſe ye?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: At the ſack of Antioch,
Where my good Unckle di'de, and I was taken,
By a meane ſouldier taken: by this Prince,
This noble Prince, redeemed from him againe,
Where ever ſince I have remained his ſervant.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: My joyes are now too full: welcome Enanthe,
Mine owne, my deareſt, and my beſt Enanthe.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And mine too deſperate.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You ſhall not thinke ſo,
This is a peace indeed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I hope it ſhall be,
And aske it firſt.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Moſt royall ſir, ye have it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I once more beg it thus.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: You muſt not be deni'd ſir.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: By me, I am ſure he muſt not: ſure he ſhall not;
Kneeling I give it too; kneeling I take it;
And from this houre, no envious ſpight ere part us.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: The gods give happy joyes; all comforts to ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: My new Enanthe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come, beat all the Drums up,
And all the noble inſtruments of war:
Let 'em fill all the Kingdome with their ſounds;
And thoſe the brazen arch of heaven breake through,
While to the Temple we conduct theſe two.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: May they be ever loving, ever young,
And ever worthy of thoſe lines they ſprong;
May their faire iſſues walke with time along.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: And hang a coward now; and there's my ſong.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: VVOuld ſome man would inſtruct me what to ſay:
For this ſame Prologue, uſuall to a play,
Is tied to ſuch an old forme of Petition;
Men muſt ſay nothing now beyond commiſſion:
The cloakes we weare, the leggs we make, the place
We ſtand in, muſt be one; and one the face.
Nor alter'd, nor exceeded; if it be,
A generall hiſſe, hangs on our levitie:
We have a Play, a new Play to play now,
And thus low in our Plaies behalfe we bow;
We bow to beg your ſuffrage, and kind eare;
If it were naught, or that it might appeare
A thing boy'd up by prayer, Gentlemen,
Beleeve my faith, you ſhould not ſee me then.
Let them ſpeake then have power to ſtop a ſtorme,
I never lov'd to feele a houſe ſo warme:
But for the Play, if you dare credit me,
I thinke it well: All new things you ſhall ſee,
And thoſe diſpos'd to all the mirth that may;
And ſhort enough we hope: and ſuch a Play
You were wont to like: ſit nobly then, and ſee:
If it miſcarrie, pray looke not for me.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: I Am not cur'd yet throughlie; for beleeve
I feele another paſſion that may grieve
All over me I feele it too: and now
It takes me cold, cold, cold, I know not how:
As you are good men helpe me, a Carowſe
May make me love you all, all here i'th' houſe,
And all that comes to ſee me doatingly:
Now lend your hands; and for your curteſie,
The next imployment I am ſent upon,
I'le ſweare you are Phiſitians, the wars none.
